Review title: "The nearest house is miles away, and the closest town is a half day's walk"
Review_body: Well acted by its small primary cast, a woman, following the curious death of her father, marries and relocates to an isolated manor (known informally as Crimson Peak, due to the red clay underground, which seeps through the snow, and turns the white snow deep red) with her new husband, and his sister.All is not right, as his sister proves to be more chilling than the new fallen snow, and her obsession with serving her tea quickly becomes odd. Isolation further sets in, as the snowfall comes, and seals them in, "The nearest house is miles away, and the closest town is a half day's walk" we are told.Great looking sets, lighting, and costumes in this Gothic romance with horror undertones, which the trailer misleadingly made look like a supernatural horror. A few surprising burst of graphic violence seemed out of place, her father having her face struck against a sink three or four times, cracking a huge hole in his skull, causing his death was quite difficult to watch, but that was doubtlessly the intent.The CG ghosts were, I felt, out of place, and far too gory, clashing with the elegant story being told, and I thought it went on one scene too long. Still worth watching for its story, acting, and set design, especially in time for Halloween.

Review title: Moody, Atmospheric and Visually Stunning Haunted Romance
Review_body: I find that I enjoy Guillermo Del Toro's CRIMSON PEAK a little more with each time I watch it. I found myself a little disappointed upon first viewing because, to be fair, I had gone in with different expectations. I'd gotten the impression from the little bit of promotional material I'd seen that this was going to be a haunted house horror movie. This is not the case. CRIMSON PEAK is a romance/thriller that just so happens to feature a handful of ghosts. Once I'd course-corrected my expectations and watched it again, I found it far more enjoyable. I've seen it a few times now (including a viewing just for Del Toro's commentary track) and I almost wouldn't mind watching it again. CRIMSON PEAK is the tale of Edith Cushing (Mia Wasikowska). Following the death of her mother from black cholera when she was very young, Edith believes she encountered her mother's ghost who bore a dire warning, "When the time comes, beware of Crimson Peak." Years later, Edith has grown into an intelligent woman who aspires to write but finds resistance from publishers who seem uncomfortable with a female writer turning in ghost stories instead of romance novels. She finds a man who happens to enjoy her writing in Thomas Sharpe (Tom Hiddleston), a baronet from England who has come to America to seek financing for his red clay mining machine from Edith's father and his investment associates. Much to her father's chagrin, Edith and Thomas seem to hit it off and, following the unfortunate (and suspicious) death of her father, the two of them leave for England to live on Thomas's estate, Allerdale Hall. It's not an easy transition as the mansion is in disrepair, slowly sinking into the red clay on which it's built, and Thomas's sister Lucille (Jessica Chastain) doesn't seem too keen on Edith. For the first time in years, Edith finds herself experiencing terrifying ghostly visions and learns that Allerdale Hall goes by another name in winter time: Crimson Peak.Anyone familiar with Del Toro's films knows what to expect here and, once again, he delivers in spades. The visual styling of CRIMSON PEAK is absolutely fantastic. The period costume design for late nineteenth century and the recreation of early Buffalo, New York are great, and the actual design of the estate on Crimson Peak is amazing. Not a single detail was spared in creating Del Toro's haunted mansion and a peek into the behind-the-scenes documentaries will attest to how much effort went into bringing the man's vision to life. The titular mansion is just as much a character in the film as Edith, Thomas, Lucille, and the ghosts. The ghosts in this movie are some of the coolest designs I've seen in a movie in years. A lot of modern ghost movies tend to have the same basic design tropes: paleness in color, spastic movements, and the use of jump scares, etc. For the most part, Del Toro avoids all of these and instead goes for a more traditional approach. Ghost float will float into frame, perhaps in the blurred background of a shot and coming into focus once the character becomes aware of their presence. They'll crawl up through the floor or just be hovering right there in the open air. The ghosts aren't just pale versions of their living counterparts with shaggy hair and pupil-less eyes or something; they're warped caricatures of their former selves, twisted and maimed with the injuries that led to their death. The ghosts in this movie come in two varieties: crimson red (for ghosts specific to Allerdale Hall) and black (for Edith's mother andone other). Del Toro used a combination of visual effects and practical costuming to accomplish his bizarre creations and the final product is one that stands out as unique in a sea of ghost movies where the dead often seem interchangeable between titles. For Del Toro's usual standard of visual style alone, CRIMSON PEAK is a solid recommend.The story is what I've seen referred to as "Gothic horror" but I don't know enough about the Gothic style to really comment on it. What I can vouch for is how engaging I found the tale of love, murder, hauntings, and a few disturbing surprises that arise once Edith finds herself in too deep. I'm really hesitant to go into too great of detail because I wouldn't want to spoil any plot developments. I mean, we can tell from early on that there is a side to Thomas and Lucille that we aren't seeing. There is some sort of plot afoot and Lucille appears to be the cold, calculating mastermind behind it. She's cold and unfriendly to just about everyone and, while she supports Thomas and Edith's marriage, she doesn't seem too thrilled about it. Jessica Chastain is wonderful per usual and it's cool to see her in a slimier, evil character. I'm so accustomed to seeing her as the no-nonsense, woman-in-charge sort (ZERO DARK THIRTY, THE MARTIAN, INTERSTELLAR, etc.) that I enjoyed watching her let loose with the certifiably insane Lucille. Tom Hiddleston also proves an effective leading man; the two of them steal the spotlight while Wasikowska's soft-spoken Edith isn't as intriguing a character to keep pace with them. Charlie Hunnam has a minor role as Edith's childhood friend and exists primarily for his interference in the end where Del Toro plays on the cinema trope of the dashing hero rushing in to rescue the damsel in distress. It makes for a fun twist on your expectations. Guillermo Del Toro is a masterful storyteller, and CRIMSON PEAK was a pleasant surprise that only gets better for me. It might not be what everyone is expecting (again, it's not specifically a horror film but a romance/drama with horror elements) but I encourage them to give it a shot.

Review title: Del Toro has Become a Slave to His Own Style
Review_body: Long gone are the days when the versatile Guillermo Del Toro reached the apex of his horror writing and directing. The Devil's Backbone (2001) and Cronos (1993) are completely out of the public consciousness, their fresh and economic twists on intelligent horror films a relic of their time. Yet Del Toro's public persona is one that still bores into our perception. The mere mentioning of his name conjures the spooky atmospherics of Pan's Labyrinth (2006) and the television phenomena The Strain (2014-Present). In short, to the masses, Del Toro equals horror. So why then is Crimson Peak, his newest directorial effort such an underwhelming disappointment? Well maybe it's because it's not a horror film.Crimson Peak opens with a young Edith Cushing (Wasikowska) staring into the middle distance. There's a bellowing blizzard, damp blood red clay penetrates through the snow and there's a deep cut on her cheek, the kind of cut we see on heroes who have seen heavy things yet the makeup artist still wants them to look good. After a brief prologue which flashes back to Edith's childhood, we arrive in Buffalo, New York. Edith is an aspiring writer who catches the eye of the handsome but mysterious Baron Thomas Sharpe (Hiddleston). They marry hot on the heels of a family tragedy and she's transported to Crimson Peak, his estate in England where all is not as it seems. Also catering to the atmosphere is Lucille (Chastain), Thomas's cold and domineering sister.Starting with the good, the film is at many times a marvel to look at. The period detail bursts from the screen and the color schemes, especially during the haunted mansion scenes are jarringly beautiful. The film couples its filigree with the intensity of Dan Lausten's slick cinematography which cushions the film's slower moments with dynamic camera-work. Additionally there are nuggets of advertence signalling to better stories by Daphne du Maurier, Edgar Allan Poe, Anthony Berkeley Cox and Charlotte Bronte. Personally I found the parallels to be less of homages and more blatant rip-offs, but I suppose one man's imitation is another man's emulation. Based on images alone one can almost forgive the film's faults...almost.Years of subjecting himself to Hellboy fandom has probably made Del Toro comfortable with condescending to the audience. The screenplay isn't just cliché as it is aggressively banal with the creators tipping their hand and answering questions the audience hadn't yet asked. In case your mind was wondering too far from the screen to pick up less than subtle visual cues, all information is regurgitated by lesser characters like week old cud. Things made dull are shrouded in mystery while things meant to be mysterious simply aren't. The only mystery I was looking to solve was why would twice nominated Academy Award nominee Jessica Chastain pick such a project. Then again she did do Mama (2013), so maybe she has an affinity to trivial horror.In reality all stars will likely survive this film unscathed but at this point Del Toro has become a slave to his own style. Del Toro and Hiddleston both have been attending press junkets and doing late night interviews insisting Crimson Peak is less of a straight up haunted house film and more of a Gothic romance. Right; this is despite the studio's marketing strategy squeezing every jump scare and ghastly ghoul into the trailer. I suppose they have to recoup $30 million budget somehow. I personally knew I was in a long slog five minutes in when Edith explains to a would be publisher "It's not really a ghost story, the ghost is more a metaphor." It certainly was a metaphor. A metaphor for boredom and awkward fan service a la Tom Hiddleston necking.

Review title: "Crimson Peak"- Though perhaps a bit of a misstep for director Guillermo del Toro, it still satisfies overall thanks to its delightful melodrama and gorgeous visuals...
Review_body: Perhaps the most tragically overlooked and criminally under- recognized artist living and working today, mastermind filmmaker Guillermo del Toro has long-been a favorite of mine, with a wonderfully poetic and visually arresting body of work that captures the imagination like few others. Whether it be with his delightful comic- book features like "Hellboy" or "Blade II", or for his more provocative fantasy-dramas like "Pan's Labyrinth" and "Cronos", del Toro proves over and over that he is a true cinematic genius.Unfortunately, even the most brilliant minds make missteps now and again, and while I do think that del Toro has never made a single "bad" film, his 2015 release "Crimson Peak" is definitely his largest stumble. A sort-of domestic period drama and thriller told within the confines of an old-fashioned ghost-story, "Crimson Peak" seems like an ideal piece of subject matter for its writer/director. Especially with its rampant echoes of his excellent prior film "The Devil's Backbone", to which this almost feels like a spiritual successor. However, a number cracks around the edges do derail it at times, making it a somewhat middling entry into his ever-growing filmography. Though thankfully, his continued keen use of poetic melodrama and his eye for stunning visuals do help it to excel and overcome many of its faults. It may objectively be del Toro's worst film... but it's still a Guillermo del Toro movie through-and- through.At the tail end of the 1800's, Edith Cushing (Mia Wasikowska), a struggling author and daughter of a wealthy American businessman falls in love with English baronet Sir Thomas Sharpe (Tom Hiddleston), whom is seeking funding for a clay-mining invention of his own design. After a series of bizarre and disturbing events including the murder of her father, Edith marries Thomas and runs away with him, set to live with him at his massive home with he and his somewhat unhinged sister Lucille (Jessica Chastain). However, it soon becomes clear that now all is well, as Edith is haunted by increasingly disturbing spectral figures during the night and comes under scrutiny and scorn from Lucille. And so, Edith sets out to learn the dark secrets of the manor and tries to piece together just what's happening...The performances are uniformly fantastic. Hiddleston and Chastain steal the show in absolutely fantastic roles as siblings who may have some dark secrets. Hiddleston plays his role to perfection, as you can never quite guess his true motivations or feelings, and Chastain is just deliciously vile as a perpetually slimy and troubling figure. Wasikowska is also a blast of grace and creates a very compelling and instantly likable protagonist for the audience to follow. Though she can be a bit too much of a blank slate at times, I found it worked, as she served not only as a lead, but also as an excellent surrogate for the audience to place themselves into. Supporting roles by the likes of Charlie Hunnam and Jim Beaver are also very well- played.Guillermo del Toro's wonderful sense of direction and fine melodramatic writing with co-scribe Matthew Robins is the other part of the puzzle to what makes the film work. This is just a gorgeous film and del Toro's trademark flowing camera-work, gorgeous stylized lighting and top-notch design sense make it a wonder to behold. You've never seen anything quite like it. It oozes a Gothic atmosphere and just drips of style. I particularly admired an ongoing motif that treats a deep red clay that's being mined like blood, as it literally oozes through the ground and stains the snow- covered fields a deep crimson hue. The script is also quite tight and well constructed, as tension builds with each passing moment. Robins and del Toro also inject plenty of the delightful and quirky melodrama that has come to define much of del Toro's work, and it compliments the story quite well. It almost feels more akin to an old-fashioned fable than a modern film with its wonderfully antiquated dialog and broad strokes of storytelling magic.However, there are some big faults at play- most notably the wonky pacing during the first half of the film and the inconsistent sense of tone and genre. The first half of the movie has an almost bipolar feeling... You'll be treated to some wonderfully moody sequences of fear and likable scenes of romance, but it doesn't have a strong flow. Some scenes rocket by, lopping on on-the-nose exposition dialog in a haphazard way, while others drag on perhaps a bit too long, bordering on the boring. It can be very jarring on your first viewing. I also really take some issues with the film's treatment of tone and genre. As I mentioned above, the film takes many cues from del Toro's prior work "The Devil's Backbone"- a movie that used the supernatural elements in a more passive way that merely guided the audience along the journey. The ghosts in that movie were only a small but very integral part of the story. The issue I have here (and this is not spoiling anything) is that the supernatural elements are too passive. From the first act of the film, you get a sense that the spirits at play are not really all that necessary, and were merely added because del Toro wanted to make a movie with ghosts in it. So it can make the scenes played for straight horror a bit off-kilter.Still, thanks to likable performances, del Toro's trademark spellbinding direction and a fun enough script, "Crimson Peak" overcomes these issues and remains a fairly fun and compelling watch. It might not quite be the masterpiece of Gothic romance and devious supernatural horror we wanted, but it's a serviceable film and is still well worth-seeing for those who might be interested.I give it a pretty good 7 out of 10.

Review title: The bleeding snow and Gothic ambiance produce a good horror spectacle, but the haunting simply follows lady in creepy dress formula.
Review_body: Comparison is bound to made with Pan's Labyrinth, since Crimson Peak has Del Toro's trademark twisted fairy tale feel and desolated last century setting. It is a peculiarly and aesthetically pleasing horror, but the clash between romance and thriller is neither as bold nor magical as previous incursion. The simplistic nature works more like The Woman in Black, although Del Toro's presentation does separate it from other entities.The plot revolves around Edith (Mia Wasikowska) who is charmed by Thomas Sharpe (Tom Hiddleston) in the first act. After she's drawn to their lives, she discovers that Sharpe siblings might just hide some ominous secrets. It's a straightforward deceit and debauchery story with a few rather daunting apparitions thrown into the mix.The first noticeable edge Crimson Peak has is the flamboyant style of visual. Those who have watched Hellboy 2 or Pan's Labyrinth should be familiar with this graphical flair. The colors are splendidly painted, nearly every scenes have bleak backdrop yet glossy golden or scarlet undertone. Either it's from outlandish outfits or clever use of vista, the scenes where these characters interact appear nearly surreal.Tom Hiddleston creates a suave gentleman persona who also seems secretive and distant at times. Jessica Chastain as Lucille, the sister, is very unnerving. She's almost oozing sinister air, which is complimented well by her typical dark dress, and also a good contender for Disney lady villain. Compared to the two, Mia Wasikowska as the female lead is rather timid. She's not entirely bad, but some of her expressions don't convey the necessary dread.This also translates to the horror. Crimson Peak has one of the creepiest apparitions on romance themed movies, a couple of its scenes might just surpass full-fledged horror movies in recent times. However, the reaction from Edith is shockingly dull, almost seemingly lacking self-preservation instinct despite visited by constant nocturnal phantoms.I don't care how suave Tom Hiddleston can make excuses, the mansion has hole on the roof. While it's good for panoramic shots for falling leaves or snow, it's a clear sign of hazard. There are also patches of blood-stained dirt that seeps through the living room. Those anomalies coupled with strange occurrences and screams of night terror, Edith should realize the danger sooner, but in too many scenes she's too oblivious, partially for the sake of plot.Crimson Peak is a strange marriage of romance and horror. Both aspects have glimpses of brilliance, yet they never culminate in conclusion beyond what other ghost stories have told. Having benefit of classy presentation and eerie atmosphere, it's still a highly presentable horror flick. However, for those looking for another grand tale or magical journey from Del Toro, Crimson Peak might not reach such zenith.

Review title: Not what I expected but I've come to appreciate it
Review_body: Guillermo del Toro's "Crimson Peak" is very much a throwback to a bygone era of horror fiction. At first glance, the movie appears to be a standard haunted house tale like countless others that we've seen through the years. However, upon closer inspection the story's true inspiration turns out to be the archetypal gothic romances that laid the foundation for much of the horror fiction that has since followed. Successful examples of this approach in Hollywood are few and far between, with the likes of "Rebecca" (1940) & "Dragonwyck" (1946) being among the few that spring to mind.To be sure, there are indeed horrific elements in "Crimson Peak" but I would hesitate to classify it as an out-and-out horror movie. del Toro is obviously familiar with the basic ingredients of a gothic romance and he wields them expertly in crafting his own story. While you might have a point in saying that that the formula is extremely derivative, it is nevertheless a formula that works. It basically wouldn't be gothic romance without a vulnerable heroine, a dashing but mysterious suitor and an ancestral home whose hauntings are both literal and figurative.Given the somewhat rigid guidelines of gothic romance, del Toro's script is actually more intricate than it might seem at first. The movie is full of metaphors, many of them visual. This imbues life into material whose presentation could have been routine in the hands of another director. In particular, the use of colour in the film is especially striking.Of course, a script like this needs actors/actresses who are up to the task of bringing it to life. Mia Wasikowska is suitably delicate for the role of the young lady who becomes ensnared in a perilous situation. Tom Hiddleston & Jessica Chastain have the juiciest roles and neither of them disappoint in supplying an air of subtle menace. Charlie Hunnam's performance is a bit below these three in my estimation but he still makes a serviceable counterpoint to Hiddleston. The supporting cast is similarly satisfactory but ultimately nothing to write home about.del Toro's direction is well handled, as always. The beautiful visuals do not come at the expense of generating & sustaining suspense. The visual effects are a bit too grotesque for my taste but others may feel differently. The sets & costumes are also exquisite. Overall, the movie shows meticulous attention to detail in virtually every area of the production.All of that being said, "Crimson Peak" definitely isn't a movie for everyone. If you're looking for horror then you might not find enough of it. If you're looking for romance then you might be turned off by the horrific trappings. To be honest, while I admired del Toro's craft the first time I watched this movie, the story felt a bit weak. It was only upon rewatching it that I was able to appreciate the intricacies of the presentation and appreciate it for what it is rather than what I initially expected it to be.

Review title: Pedestrian story covered by stunning visuals.
Review_body: As has become his modus operandi, Guillermo del Toro's latest offers a feast for the eyes whilst working within a pedestrian story. This Victorian-era Gothic horror is a visually sensational experience boasting gorgeous music-video-style imagery, painstakingly detailed production design and lush, immersive photography that trickles with creepiness. But del Toro missteps with narrative and tone; the former is too plodding and predictable, whilst the latter is neither scary enough to be a great horror nor twisty enough to be a great thriller. Thus Crimson Peak feels entirely inconsequential and must rely heavily on its visual flair, including splendidly designed CGI ghosts and blood-splattering gore, to keep the audience's attention. Nabbing such a talented group of actors doesn't hurt del Toro's cause either, Australia's own Mia Wasikowska heading up a cast that also features Tom Hiddleston, Charlie Hunnam and, with a show stealing turn, Jessica Chastain. Lovers of classical horror will find plenty to delight in and fans of del Toro (like me) will relish his usual quirky spark, everybody else may be a tad dissatisfied.

Poor Guillermo del Toro. No matter how many unique, visionary works he generates throughout his career, each subsequent project is still fated to, somewhat unfairly, receive the inevitable dismissal of "well, it's no Pan's Labyrinth..." Okay, so as problems go, struggling to live up to one of the most sublime pictures of modern cinema you've already made isn't so bad. Still, it's too tantalizing to resisting envisioning how transformative del Toro attacking a new filmic genre could be. But down that path lies madness. And, sure enough, just as Pacific Rim was fun but ultimately soulless (again, with the qualifier "for del Toro"), Crimson Peak, despite ticking all the right genre boxes, is a visually rich but resonantly hollow and disappointingly under-thought Gothic melodrama pastiche. Although he's undeniably the main selling point, the trick might be to avoid viewing the film within the lens of 'a Guillermo del Toro' film, as his work here is sadly more akin to a filmmaker doing a Guillermo del Toro impression. And that's the film's biggest fright of all. First off: although the film's plodding script begins with the dull stinger "ghosts are real", it is important to note that Crimson Peak is not a horror film. It just isn't. Though occasional ghosts do rear their rattly, bloody heads, del Toro is slavish enough to Gothic romance tropes that such apparitions are largely part of the set dressing more than driving the plot in any significant way. Accurate? Yes. But in terms of spooky creature feature fun? Booooo. Still: genre fidelity is fair enough. So what's the point of Crimson Peak, then? Frankly, I'm not sure the film offers much more in-depth than 'gothic stuff is fun'. Pastiche for pastiche's sake never flies well though, and this gossamer-thin immateriality eats away at the film like its giant moths that flutter to and fro throughout (and if you think that metaphor was clumsy and crass, you'll certainly have no patience for the film as a whole). The story is a rote, overlong, fundamentally predictable cesspool of 'bad people doing bad things for bad reasons', all the more pallid by the lack of any supernatural motivations behind it, and poorly served by an infuriatingly obvious script ruining any sense of eerie mystery. Our protagonist, drably embodied by Mia Wasikowska, is a serviceably fragile but feisty Victorian ghost story author, but too bland to grow particularly attached to (but hey – at least her initial suitor, a goodhearted doctor played by the comically miscast Charlie Hunnam, only shares limited screen time with her). As she aimlessly wanders about, spouting meta clunkers like "the ghosts are metaphors" (d'oh), things don't look promising.Thankfully, when's she's whisked into a whirlwind romance, things become briefly more titillating. Here, thanks are due to Tom Hiddleston at his suave, seductive, waltzing best, sure to elicit swoons in the most chaste of audiences. He's given little to do but brood and gripe about clay mining in the film's second act, but his initial work is on-point, finally gifting the film with a pulse. Nonetheless, even this – through no fault of Hiddleston – quickly dries up into an artificial seductive montage so rushed and clumsily foreboding (with a dash of unnecessarily graphic violence) it verges on Twilight territory. Now that's spooky. Ah, so the point must be atmosphere, one muses, resisting the temptation to steal a fourth glance at one's watch. Unsurprisingly, del Toro tangibly breathes a sigh of relief when released from the cumbersome society sequences, and free to sink his teeth into his titular house of horrors. This creaking, crumbling labyrinth allows the set and sound designers to flex their muscles, and relinquishes a glut of much-needed customarily grimly beautiful images, finally rousing those of us who dozed off after Hiddleston's candlelit waltz. In a particularly inspired touch, the red clay underneath the house's foundation leaks up through the snow like blood stains. Cooooool. Film studies students will crow at the essay waiting to be written about the bold use of primary colours towards thematic ends, but the film finally getting creepy is enough to alleviate anyone's spirits. Still (uh oh), it's hard to banish the pesky wish that the oddly sanitized set showcased more of del Toro's inventively ramshackle spirit. Think of the delightfully clumsy whimsy of Hellboy II's Troll Market, for example, and try not to be disappointed at how conventionally Crimson Peak's manor looms by comparison. This is doubly apparent with the film's lumbering bloody spectres, whose lazy designs don't benefit from del Toro's 'show in plain sight' approach to visual frights, especially when trussed up with every 'what's-behind-that-door-aha-it's-a- screeching-musical-cue' cliché in the horror book. Increasingly, it's hard to suppress dark mumblings of del Toro's wings being clipped by Hollywood convention – all of the budgetary gleam with none of the heart. Finally, after an eternity of slow-burning tension (read: lots of brooding, tea, and moths), it's really only at the film's finale that sh*t gets real. This is largely thanks to Jessica Chastain, the film's greatest asset. After patiently biding her time through redundant scene after scene of ominously looming, expertly allowing terrifying surges of fury to crack through her glacial composure, Chastain is finally let off her chain enough to show the frenzied, Jack Torrance lunacy she's hinted at throughout. The scenery echoes her, belching up enough fog and clay to match the on screen blood, and hey – we're finally in a del Toro horror movie! Naturally, it doesn't last, as stupid deus-ex-machina clichés are thrown in our faces, spoiling the macabre fun. Finally, we're left chewing on the film's moral: you have to experience horror to write about horror. Well, if that's the case, after the spectre of an unimaginative – nay, boring – Guillermo del Toro ghost story, I'm about ready to pen my chilling masterpiece. -6/10

Review title: Gothic Horror? NO! Chilling drama? NO! Boring soap? YES!
Review_body: Usually it's a good thing if you can't define a movie by just one genre since that often gives the viewer more than they bargained for. Unfortunately Crimson Peak does not do anything convincing no matter the genre you favour, it just disappoints.Crimson Peak starts real well. It does not waste any time to draw the viewer in. Right from the start we are served one creepy scene that serves as bait and basically tricks you into believing that at least the film will be compelling. And the haunting setting and other visuals back this feeling up. However at one point it feels like details about the supposed mystery are prolonged and avoided so strongly that very soon I suspected that there is not that much of a mystery. Here I was waiting to be dazzled by some awesome twist only to be let down by the incredible poor storytelling. Whatever was build up suspense wise (mostly by visuals) was immediately gone and turned Crimson Peak into a real bore fest. Mind you it's never super bad but it's not good either. Seeing how Guillermo del Toro normally is a reliable director I can't help but feel that he is slipping. His show The Strain also is filled with incredible poor plot developments. Crimson Peak is so much worse since none of the characters are remotely interesting or compelling. I did not care about any of them. Much emphasis is put on the romantic relationship between Thomas Sharpe (Tom Hiddleston) and Edith Cushing (Mia Wasikowska). And I did not buy any second of it. Not that their acting was that bad but the plot failed to show us the sexual tension and love between them. Both Thomas and Edit act like idiots since there were many opportunities to take action. Nothing prevented them to do so. If the plot had given us some real reasons I could have accepted that. Surprise surprise the plot even fails to do such a simple task. Seriously at one point I just wanted Crimson Peak to be over with cause everything was so pointless and all for the sake of romance that was barely there.By the time things get revealed to you it does not really matter since you will have figured out what is going on long before that. It's safe to say that Crimson Peak is incredibly underwhelming and a total disappointment. I can't recommend this. Only good enough to watch very late at night or a rainy Sunday afternoon.
A good horror where the presence of ghosts is overshadowed by the comparison of the diabolical plan of the two brothers to keep the house in which they live for life.

I love Del Toro but this is massively ramped up to 11 ands in a highly camp mess. The early scenes work, dealing with class and snobbery with an air of Martin Scorsese's The Age of Innocence. There's swirling camerawork, extravagant production design; piano-playing and waltzing. And moments of excessive, extreme violence.In the second half, the action switches to the decaying English mansion house, and goes off the rails. It chucks everything into the mix, steals massively from Rebecca; the plot is clearly predictable and it collapses into absurdity.Del Toro is obviously enjoying himself, but i'm not sure the audience is. At least Chastain enjoys herself in a wonderfully flamboyant performance, part Mrs Danvers and part bride of Frankenstein.

Review title: A Beautiful And Entertaining Guillermo Del Torro Masterpiece.
Review_body: While watching this beautiful motion picture one thought kept flickering through my mind; this is what a modern Hammer film should look like - it so reminded me of the classic '60's and '70's films.Guillermo Del Torro has created another masterpiece filled with vivid and beautiful imagery and superb transitions between the light - happy - and dark -eerie - atmospheres, which work well on the emotions. Along with superb acting from the cast and a potent story, with the help of Matthew Robins, we are given the tale of twisted love and greed, which builds slowly with twists and turns throughout.What always surprises me most is that Del Torro takes some of the nastiest parts of the human psyche and the violent actions they include and shows them in such a gorgeous way while never glorifying or condoning them is amazing.This is the story of Edith Cushing, lovingly portrayed by Mia Wasikowska, a solitary and intelligent woman trying to make her way as an author in a man's world. She meets and falls in love with Thomas Sharpe, played elegantly by Tom Hiddleston, who is in town trying to raise funds for his mining machine from her father, Carter Cushing, who is admirably portrayed by Jim Beaver. However, her father doesn't like Thomas and does everything he can to stand in the way of their relationship. It's only after his death that Edith is free to wed Thomas and move out to Crimson Peak.As the days pass, Edith begins to realise that maybe her father was right, there's something not quite right with Thomas and his sister Lucille, strongly portrayed by Jessica Chastain... or the house they live in...I fell in love with this film right from the start. It's so stylish with its lighting, camera angles, and sound, that it fits perfectly with the era in which it's set. Even the End Credits are beautiful to watch. There are a lot of directors trying too hard to be stylish and here Del Torro makes it appear effortless. The special effects are really good, the one scene where the ghost is dragging itself up and along the floor is pretty creepy. I also liked the effect of the clay on the snow, turning it blood red, that was a nice touch.I would recommend this movie to everyone - it now resides at the top of my favourite Del Torro movies.

Review title: A very stylish gothic love story
Review_body: A baronet from England arrived to their town with his sister Lucille and Edith fell in love with him while she was receiving warning from the ghost of her mother about crimson peak. Lucille killed her father and the scene was very brutal as she hit his head against the sink at the club's bathroom until it was cracked open. And then Thomas married her and take her to England with him. They started living in their dilapidated mansion with Thomas's machines for mining and red clay mine beneath the house. Butterflies in the attic, the hole in the roof, the basement with red clay and the lift and very gothic architecture of the house provided a strong atmosphere. Edith discovered some cylindrical phonographs and listened to them and found out they were the previous lovers of his husband and the Italian one was warning whoever listening to it about them trying to kill her by the poison in tea. She wanted to leave but they were snowed in. The eye doctor from her town in America arrived to the mansion because he was suspicious of Edith's fathers death and talked to the detective of the man and found out that Thomas is already married. Edith caught them making love in the attic and Lucille threw her off the rails. They were lovers and the girl killed her mother the one ghost that Edith saw with a cleaver in her head. He wanted to take her with him but Lucille stabbed him and Thomas faked finishing him and hid him in the basement because he was in love with Edith. Lucille couldn't accept his brother lover falling in love with someone else and stabbed him in the face. He died and she went after Edith. She took out the cleaver from the basement the one she killed her mother and they went out in the white snow and red clay capped garden. Edith could kill her when she was distracted with the ghost of Thomas and the doctor carried him away from the house as some people coming towards the house. It was a very stylish movie and I liked the mining machine of Thomas, the doctor's design to see ghosts, those cylindrical phonographs, gothic mansions and all but the script was a little bit weak and I expected a more surprising final as we already knew from the very beginning that Edith survives. But still it was definitely a nice gothic horror fairy tale about an aspiring young writer falling in love with a dangerous man and couldn't save herself from him despite his mother's ghost's warnings.

Long drawn out with ghosts that really are superfluous to the plot. Some mediocre acting and silly storyline.A really mixed bag of nuts. Literally and figuratively.Usual del Toro cinematographic brilliance. Amazing sets. A crazy ghoulish mansion that is superb!But these can't save a pretty boring and predictable and oh, so silly plot.

Review title: Not a ghost story, a story with some ghosts in it
Review_body: This film took me a little by surprise. I expected a chilling supernatural horror, which this is definitely not.It is a story about family and betrayal set in Victorian times. Yes the walking dead are very prevalent but don't actually impact the story.The production and direction gives the film a 'classic' feel about it. Scenes are transitioned through dissolving black screens and the opening scene is closed with a zooming shot of an old leather bound book opening.I enjoyed this, the use of colour (especially in the red clay) and the attention of detail in the sets and scenery give the film a feeling of quality.Scares are very rare and don't expect a lot of action. Most of the drama takes place in parlours and ball room.A lot slower and less scary than I expected but very well crafted and enjoyable.

After receiving an ominous warning from the ghost of her dead Mother, Edith- the daughter of an American Industrialist- is seduced and lured to England by a charming young Baron and his sister- whose intentions are neither benevolent, nor transparent.Upon moving into the Baron's dilapidated, yet stately, home- after the suspicious death of her father- Edith is, again, visited by spirits of the dead, reminding her of her mother's warning: to be wary of something known as the "Crimson Peak".But this is not the only warning Edith received, she was also told never to wander into the lower levels of the mansion, by both her husband, and his sister.It's not long before she discovers what Crimson Peak means. It is a phenomenon that occurs when a bright red ore becomes liquefied and leeches into the snow, staining it a bright red. The ore being the resource her husband is trying to exploit with his invention.While it is evident from the very beginning, that the Baron and his sister have something to hide- it's not exactly clear what that is. Only after Edith is given a letter, does she start to suspect that she is not the first woman to be in this position...the Baron has been married before. And she further suspects that it is the spirits of these women whom have been haunting her, since taking up residence at the Hall.Eventually, she manages to uncover their plot: to lure in wealthy young women, so that they can kill them with poison, and cash in on their inheritance. But she is both horrified and flabbergasted when she discovers the reasons behind why they have been doing this...since first killing their mother at the ages of 12 & 14.Meanwhile, a childhood friend who adored her- and was suspicious about her Father's death- also managed to discover that brother-sister duo were essentially serial killers, preying on wealthy young women with no close heirs. So he traveled from America to England to get her back and bring her home.Inevitably leading to the film's wild conclusion.This is a really beautifully shot film, as you would expect from Guillermo Del Toro. The scenery, mise en scene, and cinematography are all top notch. But they really skimp on the ghosts, which are just cheap CGI renderings- and look terribly out of place. So that was highly disappointing, but it's to be expected, I guess.The story plods along pretty slowly throughout the majority of the film, but it really picks up in the end- so it's all building up to that. Basically, the whole thing is oriented around the series of romance angles, that are interwoven throughout the storyline...but I won't go into them here, as that would essentially act as a spoiler.So just watch it and see for yourself.6 out of 10.

Review title: One of the finest examples of Gothic horror
Review_body: (85%) A wonderfully handsome Gothic horror that may not be the most scary film ever made, but it is by far one of the most visually stunning. The cast is top notch with big names at every turn, but it's by far the look and atmosphere dripping down from nearly every shot that's the most captivating. Even with elements of Tim Burton and Poe, this is very much a Del Toro film with its sharp attention to detail, strong build-up and painful touches of ultra, almost exploitation levels of violence that always seem to shock, yet never spoil the general quality feel. His direction is impeccable as the film and its characters are allowed to breath and have room to move and everything is far from just being a long series of dumb jump scares. There wasn't a great deal of horror released around Halloween 2015 (thanks to Mr Bond) but this will likely be one of the best entries of the year. This level of superbly crafted minute detail is what big screen entertainment is all about.

Review title: Crimson Peak is a Gothic romance that's better at looking scary then being scary
Review_body: As it is said in Crimson Peak, "Ghosts are real". I'm a believer in spirits that roam the earth, stuck in our world for one reason or another. Twice I've had a paranormal encounter. The first time I saw something was when I was about ten when my family was staying in a hotel in Riverside that was rumored to be haunted. My best friend Jason and I went exploring while my folks were out to dinner. We encountered a mirror that cracked right in front of us while a voice told us go back. The second was when again, Jason and I were going to an abandoned mill where we both saw a figure on the second floor and felt the cold chill of a hand touch our shoulders. Seeing ghosts in real life is one thing, but in cinema, the less you see the spirits the more frightening they are. It draws on the perception that the scariest thing is what ever you imagine it to be. The Haunting and The Shining are probably the best haunted house movies out there they play more on the psychology of spooks and how scary that can be. Crimson Peak attempts to bring on it's own frights.Taking place in the late 1800's, young woman Edith Cushing (played by Mia Wasikowska) is the daughter of a wealthy industrialist and is an aspiring author who writes ghost stories with the hope of being Mary Shelly rather then Jane Austin. Her latest book is turned away for not having much romance. Visiting English baronet Sir Thomas Sharpe (played by Tom Hiddleston) takes an immediate liking to Edith as he tries to raise capital for an invention from her father. He and his sister Lucile (played by Jessica Chastain) are turned away and don't blend in well with the New York upper class.Her father is unexpectedly murdered, leaving Edith little to contemplate, so she marries Thomas and moves with him back to England. She she's the dilapidated mansion he's lived on since he was a boy, which is in bad condition and is sinking into the clay-like Earth that he's trying to harvest. As Edith settles in, Thomas becomes distant while Lucile becomes more cold towards her brothers wife. Each night comes as a shock as strange noises and floating spirits are spotted. They may be trying to tell Edith of the darker story behind the house and the brother and sister who live there. As with most works by Guillermo del Toro, Crimson Peak boasts with color and grand design. This is a movie that I loved looking at despite it's dark tale. It's clearly a tribute to the Hammer horror movies of the 1970s. The whole picture is like looking at a painting from that era that I'm sure will be honored with plenty of technical awards. It manages to add on to the spookiness of the atmosphere (even if the overall movie isn't really that scary) without making it too much to overwhelm the story.Speaking of which, Crimson Peak is a Gothic love story over a horror story. It seems evident of that given how much of the action relies on how much Edith trusts her husband and new sister in law. What's interesting though as much of a writer she is, it takes her a while to see that the house has a dark past, despite given some clues that aren't that hard to figure out. The story isn't bad, it's just missing a chance to be scary in favor of looking scary. Perhaps if Crimson Peak had done a better job covering some of it's plot holes, I would have liked it more.I'll give this six Victorian era ghost photos out of ten. Crimson Peak may not be as scary as it thinks it is, I enjoyed myself while I was looking at it. I doubt I'll remember these characters and their motivations, but I will remember the house.

Review title: My second all time favorite horror film, yet it's not even that terrifying!
Review_body: Crimson Peak tells the story of Edith Cushing(Mia Wasikowska). Edith loves writing stories & wants to become an author. She meets a man named, Thomas Sharpe(Tom Hiddleston). There is an instant connection between the two. Moreover, Thomas loves Edith's latest story, which she intends to publish soon. Soon, Edith also meets Thomas' sister, Lucille Sharpe(Jessica Chastain). Lucille doesn't really warm up to Edith. Edith's childhood friend, Dr. Alan McMichael(Charlie Hunnam) & her father Carter Cushing(Jim Beaver), advise her to tread lightly, when it comes to getting involved with Thomas & Lucille Sharpe. After a terrible family tragedy, Edith decides to commit to her relationship with Thomas & move to England with him & his sister. Here, she is whisked away to an old house in rural England. After Edith starts living in the house with Thomas & Lucille, she realizes that there is something intrinsically wrong with the house. She starts to see horrifying things, & this terrifies her to the core. Crimson Peak is an outstanding film. However, let me make one thing clear. Crimson Peak is not a traditional horror movie. There are not too many jump scares to freak you out while you are watching the film. So, don't go for the film expecting it to be really scary. This movie might not be terrifying but, it's still my second all time favorite horror movie. My all time favorite horror movie is, The Woman in Black(2012). The reason this film is flawless is, it has an impeccable story with various twists & turns that you will never see coming no matter how many horror or thriller films you've watched. Director Guillermo del Toro has masterfully maintained the suspense, right till the shocking climax of the film. More than being a horror film, Crimson Peak is more a hybrid of a horror film & a suspense thriller. There is a lot of gore in the film, so anyone who gets squeamish at the sight of blood should avoid this film. The sound design is one of the highlights of the film. Every minute sound, be it the treading of the boots on the snow, the subtle creaking of the door, or the burning of the candle, can be heard like as though you're with the characters in that creepy old manor. The cinematography by Dan Laustsen & the production design by Thomas E. Sanders are equally fantastic. This film becomes creepy as hell thanks to the superb camera angles & eerie sets. Allerdale Hall is a mansion that looks majestic yet, dingy & decrepit. So, the mansion is another highlight of the film. The performances by the all star cast is another highlight of the movie. Mia Wasikowska is great as Edith Cushing. The standout performances of the film are Jessica Chastain & Tom Hiddleston as Lucille Sharpe & Thomas Sharpe respectively. Chastain's ice cold portrayal of the mysterious Lucille, is flawless. Hiddleston's vulnerable portrayal of the conflicted Thomas, is spectacular as well. Charlie Hunnam is amazing as Dr. Alan McMichael. Jim Beaver is superb in his small yet substantial role, as Carter Cushing. Burn Gorman is good as Holly. Crimson Peak is a must watch due to its extremely unique & engaging story. It must be experienced on the big screen.

Review title: How to ruin a good story.....
Review_body: More than 50 million $ spent to make this picture.Great costumes, locations, props and ambiance plus fairly good acting though hammy at times.So what's the problem?An excellent Victorian style drama about love and betrayal is totally ruined by making it about stupid not scary ghosts!Why employ first rate actors and an excellent production team when nonsensical so called supernatural rubbish completely makes a mockery of a good story...dear oh dear:3/10

As we've come to expect from a Guillermo del Toro film, Crimson Peak is nothing less than a visual feast. Luxuriant cinematography by Dan Laustsen, appropriate Gothic-inspired sets, sumptuous costumes and let it be said now, that del Toro knows how to light a set. In spite of the genre, with the setting largely confined to the traditional "haunted mansion" on the snowy moors of England, the audience is never expected to peer into expressionistic gloom and try and guess what's happening. Everything is seen with abundant character and clarity.The acting too is first class with especially great work from the two female leads in Mia Wasikowska as the heroine Edith, who is in close to 90% of the scenes and Jessica Chastain as her chief antagonist Lucille, who is required to play a progressively threatening and more domineering role as the storyline moves forward. Tom Hiddleston is more than competent as money-seeking British knight with secrets Sir Thomas, who is seen less in the second half of the film, as his sister Lucille grows in prominence. And Charlie Hunnam and Jim Beaver are not short-changed, when it comes to the writing of their support characters.Guillermo del Toro has not tried to hide the fact publicly that Crimson Peak tries to avoid the modern pattern of creating shocks and cheap thrills, by the use of multiple jump scares and sudden loud noises. This is clearly a film paying homage to classics such as The Innocents, whereby suspense is created through the development of a brooding, increasingly threatening atmosphere.However it's clearly not a spoiler to state that this is a ghost movie and therefore the vast majority of scares we encounter in the first two acts are created by the emergence of rather horrid, terrifying CGI spectral creations who appear to frequently intimidate and frighten poor Edith. But in a shaggy dog third act twist, it becomes bleedingly obvious that these ghosts are actually supposed to be "good" and sympathetic to Edith's forbidding plight. So then we are left wondering why earlier, they felt they had to scare the crap out of her to get their message across, when we see the white ghost of Tom, looking and behaving completely differently. It's just not a consistent approach and we are left feeling that we've been conned by the cinematic equivalent of a pea and thimble trick to maintain suspense levels.Crimson Peak is a worthwhile addition to the ghost movie genre, but would arguably have been far more memorable, had it adopted a more consistent, less contrived approach with the use of its supernatural elements. I give it a 6.5/10, which is exactly its IMDB rating at time of writing and virtually the same as its Meta-critic rating. I think that's a very apt number and kind of wish I didn't have to round it up to 7.

Review title: "Crimson Peak" is a great "gothic romance" and one of Guillermo del Toro's best films.
Review_body: Guillermo del Toro is a brilliant director and a fascinating man, but also a study in contradictions. Most of his films are categorized as fantasy and/or horror, but he sees his movies as basically "political" in nature. His films usually include monsters because he feels they represent great power, but his stories are often about defeating the power of individuals or institutions. He'll describe himself as an atheist, but in the next breath add, "Once a Catholic, always Catholic, in a way". He's also said that he views art as his religion in that his commitment to it is almost spiritual. He has alternated between small, Spanish-language fantasy films and huge, English-language science fiction movies. He's best known for his writing and directing, but he's more prolific as a producer of different kinds of films. In spite of these apparent contradictions, he's not a man who doesn't understand who he is or why he does what he does. Rather, he's a director of great vision and his work is remarkably consistent in style and tone. His 2015 release, "Crimson Peak" (R, 1:59) feels like a combination of all his contradictions – and strengths."Ghosts are real, that much I know. I've seen them all my life." So intones Edith Cushing as the film opens. She makes her statement without passion or fear, but as a simple matter of fact. As a young woman submitting a novel she wrote to a potential publisher who calls it a ghost story, she protests. She says that the story just happens to have a ghost in it – as a metaphor. She may accept the existence of ghosts as a fact of life, but they scare her as much as they would any of us. The first ghost she sees is that of her mother, who died when Edith was a little girl. The frightening wispy specter dressed in black warns her daughter to "beware of Crimson Peak", but doesn't explain what that means. Damn ghosts.Yes, she sees dead people, but they know they're dead, and they don't control her life. Edith (Mia Wasikowska) may see ghosts more readily than those around her, but she's far more focused on becoming a writer. It's tough for a female author to be taken seriously in early 20th century Buffalo. She decides to mail off her manuscript – after rewriting it on one of those new-fangled typewriters, so her handwriting won't betray her gender. Busy typing in the office of her father, industrialist Carter Cushing (Jim Beaver), Edith meets Englishman Sir Thomas Sharpe (Tom Hiddleston). He's also having a hard time being taken seriously. He's looking for investors for his invention, a machine to remove clay from the ground. Carter, however, sees Thomas as a privileged aristocrat, rather than a serious entrepreneur.Edith sees something else. She's quite taken with the English gentleman, and he with her. Thomas' sister, Lady Lucille (Jessica Chastain), isn't so sure about Edith – and Edith's father isn't so sure about Thomas. Carter hires a private investigator to check into Thomas' background. What Carter learns is more than enough for Carter to want Thomas gone. Thomas leaves, but he convinces Edith to come with him – and be his bride. They marry and journey to his English estate, where a large, but dark and creepy-looking house sits, in an advancing state of decay, on a red clay hill that the locals call Crimson Peak.Edith doesn't yet know of her new home's nickname. In fact, there's a lot about the house and her new family that she doesn't know. Lucille, who also lives in the house, is as cold to Edith as that main hall with a gaping hole in its roof. Thomas ominously warns his new wife not to go below the house's main level. And then there are the ghosts. (Yes, ghosts – plural.) Edith's mom comes to call, but isn't any more forthcoming with her mysterious warnings than she was when Edith was a little girl. The other ghosts in the house are even less specific about what they want, or even who they are. Edith has suffered no harm in the house, but the secrets that she learns are terrifying and creepy – in more ways than one.This is an unusually accessible del Toro film. It's not as bizarre as "Pan's Labyrinth", as violent as the "Hell Boy" movies or as bloated as "Pacific Rim" (as good as those films are). But don't get scared. "Crimson Peak" is very much a Guillermo del Toro movie, in themes, tone and style. Built just for this film, the house is simultaneously beautiful and frightening. And you needn't go any further than the film's advertising to see indications of the director's preference for dark reddish hues. In fact, the posters make it very clear that this movie features creative and striking visuals. Besides that magnificent main set, the cinematography is gorgeous, the images of the ghosts are terrific and the costumes are incredible. At times, however, the movie feels like an expensive version of a television true crime mystery, complete with dips to black for commercial breaks, but those impressions are fleeting. This "gothic romance", as del Toro calls it, is much more than a ghost story. You could say it's a scary movie which happens to have ghosts in it. Edith would. I'd say that it's one of del Toro's best films to date. "A-"

I have seen better stuff from Guillermo del Toro, namely Cronos(1993), Mimic(1997), Hellboy (2004), Pan's Labyrinth (2006), Hellboy II: The Golden Army (2008), Pacific Rim (2013).These are all his films I have seen. I haven't yet seen The Devil's Backbone(2001), but I have heard that it is a good film. The key highlight of Del Toro's films are the special effects. Usually they are mind-blowing like Hellboy and Blade II. Also focus on intense action sequences like these above two films I mentioned.This film is a Gothic horror suspense-drama, with emphasis given on the background sets to generate an atmosphere of America in the period of 1887. The story is that of Edith Cushing (Mia Wasikowska), the young daughter of wealthy American businessman Carter Cushing (Jim Beaver), is visited by her mother's black, disfigured ghost who warns her, "Beware of Crimson Peak."The story than forward to when she is a young woman in her twenties, where her ambition is to become a successful writer. She had finished her manuscript and then gone to visit her publisher where she meets the Sir Thomas Sharpe (Tom Hiddleston), an English baronet who has come to the United States with his sister, Lucille (Jessica Chastain), to seek investors for his clay-mining invention. I shan't give any more of the story away, you will have to see it for yourselves. The problem I had with the film was the predictability. If you are an avid horror fan, this film will have little appeal to you. There is nothing new in this film that you haven't seen before. If you like suspense-thrillers you will also be disappointed. This film has an element of romance and intrigue(or should I say incest), but it is heavily watered down.The most well known actress is Jessica Chastain. The most well known actor is Jonathan Hyde, but he has a minuscule part on the film. Tom Hiddleston, Charlie Hunnam and Mia Wasikowska are all capable actors but I feel their prowess was overshadowed by a dull and predictable script. The cinematography by Dan Laustsen is brilliant, but the background music by Fernando Velázquez is inadequate. Del Toro's direction is flawless, but really he should have known that the script was inadequate by today's standards.More horror films to watch: Suspiria (1977), Dawn of the Dead(1978), The Shining(1980), The Changeling(1980), Poltergeist (1982), The Exorcist III(1990).Thanks for reading my review, live long and prosper.

Review title: The Worst Movie of Guillermo Del Toro
Review_body: I got to the late showing of Crimson Peak and it was pretty bad. I should've stayed home. At best, it's rental and if you miss altogether, you aren't missing much. The worst movie I've ever seen by Guillermo Del Toro. The first act takes too long to get going and basically shows most of the horror promised in the commercial. I did like the black ghost mother that showed up at the beginning, the best part of the film. The chemistry between Tom Hiddleston and Mia Wasikowska was non-existent and when you might say this is intentional, none of the acting was very good for that matter. Jessica Chastain had the most interesting character but her motivations were ill-explained and it all sort of fell apart at the end. Charlie Hunnam was a handsome face but really served no purpose, as did the ghosts. Instead of going for the Gothic romance, they should've done as advertised and went for horror. The movie is only entertaining when Del Toro shows his skill with the effects and the ghostly specters creep out of the floor or the doorway. The writing was terrible, the screenplay hardly makes sense. The explanation was forced and characters talk to much at the end because no understands what is going on. Overall a bad movie, even by horror movie standards.

Review title: This Gothic-Romance-Ghost-Story is a home-run for Del Toro, and I'm sure 'Crimson Peak' will remain in people's minds for a while.
Review_body: When Guillermo Del Toro makes a movie, you pay attention, but a ticket, strap yourself in the seat, and prepare your eye-holes for something that is guaranteed to thrill you, chill you, and fulfill you. With a resume that includes 'Pan's Labyrinth', 'Hellboy I & II', 'Blade II', 'Pacific Rim', and 'The Devil's Backbone', you know for sure, you're in for something special when Del Toro is involved. That brings us to his latest masterpiece of cinema, 'Crimson Peak'. Now I know that the trailers for 'Crimson Peak' paint a picture that makes this look like a straight horror film, which is not the case here.Guillermo set out to make one of those rare Gothic-Romance stories, something that hasn't been done well in a long time. There are some frightening moments in the film of course, but there aren't a ton of "jump at you" scares, which is a breath of fresh air from all of the recent horror movies as of late. Instead, this is a slow burn of terror that follows a woman who falls in love with someone who is not who he appears to be. Guillermo and Matthew Robbins's script allows enough time to set up each character with good amount of back-story, so that we may connect with them.Even the villains. Set in the late 19th century, we center on a young female author named Edith Cushing (Mia Wasikowska), who lives with her wealthy father (Jim Beaver), and is mostly courted by a local doctor named Alan (Charlie Hunnam). One day, a man comes into town by the name of Sir Thomas Sharpe (Tom Hiddleston), and with his British accent, he charms Edith and tries to secure funding from Edith's father for a new invention back in England. The two fall for each other and after an accident, Edith moves to England with Sharpe and his sister Lucille (Jessica Chastain).Once at the Sharpe estate, which is a run-down, creepy looking mansion, or something that would have suited Vincent Price and Edgar Allan Poe quite well, things take a turn for the worse. Edith begins hearing and seeing strange noises and frightening apparitions that seem to be after her, or at least trying to tell her something. All the things that go bump in the night come full force, and is executed flawlessly by Guillermo's eye. Sooner than later, Edith starts discovering who the Sharpes are and where they came from, which is not very pleasant to say the least.In between the scary moments, we get a look at the relationship between Thomas and Edith, which has a very 'Romeo and Juliet' vibe to it, but we also get the relationship angle from Lucille's angle as well. Lucille is an excellent character to watch through the entire film and see her past through stories that made her what she is today. Del Toro's camera-work has eerie similarities to Stanley Kubrick. Everything is perfectly famed and symmetrical with a ton of great tracking and slow moving shots. The pace is even on par with 'The Shining' from Kubrick, which lets all hell break loose in the finale.This Gothic-Romance-Ghost-Story is a home-run for Del Toro, and I'm sure 'Crimson Peak' will remain in people's minds for a while.Highly Recommended!

Review title: story is just incomplete and vague. very mild spoilers
Review_body: The film looks great. It seemed to have loads of qualities that I usually like. Fantasy elements. Period piece. Mystery/horror. But, where the film dies is in it's bland, under-developed plot.There's some long story about murder.. multiple murders. And that story falls about as flat as a WAffle House menu. It's because of this that the characters emotions lack any substance, and the love- story aspects of the last 10-15 minutes were complete misses for me. At that point I think miss Wasikowski could have cared less about the guy.The film just doesn't work in any way EXCEPT visually. In that aspect it's fantastic, but there's so much more to making a good film.I did like the gore. Well done, and at times a bit shocking. THe film just isn't scary either which really leaves this in the blah blah territory. It's VERY similar to "Stonehearst Asylum". That film doesn't look as good as Crimson Peak, but the story is much better and far more developed than it is here, and I actually would recommend that movie BEFORE this one, although neither is very good.Dunno is Toro will ever surpass "Pan's Labyrinth". This one wasn't even close. Looks and sounds great though.ehh... pass. 54/100 Visuals 8 Acting 8 Story 4 Script 3

Guillermo Del Toro comes an awful cropper with this movie. Just about every horror film cliche is doped out in a gorgeous-looking, appallingly-scripted film. and the thing is so silly it becomes unintentionally funny.Tom Hiddlestone is okay, Jessica Chastain gives the sort of performance she might want to leave off her CV. Mia Wasiowsaka's character is so dumb it's hilarious.The script writers obviously realised how bad it was, as they up the gore content to ridiculous levels. The last 30 minutes is pretty much just bodily injury time as everyone gets stabbed, sliced, hacked and bashed. Mia, who has been suffering from slow posioning throughout the movie's second half, becomes a shovel-wielding battler at the end. Tom, of course, reforms all of a sudden when he really does fall in love - ah bless. It's a plot twist you can spot coming a mile off. The women will be happy that he displays his arse Kirk Douglas style.Thanks for all the exposition from phonograph cylinders, handily filling in the gaps for all those audience members who are a bit dim, while at the same time ripping off Dracula. Sorry - in this post-modernist era it's a smart reference, of course for all the psueds. There are plenty of others. I'm just suprised Tom didn't have a monster bubbling in the vat, as they might as well as ripped off Frankenstein as well.I suspect this may become a great guilty pleasure in years to come. Makes me glad Del Torro's Lovecraft movie fell through.

119 minutes long, could have easily been 89 minutes, easily. Beautifully shot, I mean the colors and the visuals are spectacular. The costumes are exquisite, the attention to detail is commendable. All the actors are of the highest caliber and each absolutely commits to the role and becomes their character. The direction is spot-on, no complaints. Ah, but the script, ah but that pesky script with all those funny little words within. It's dull. Plodding. The words people say are said silly, each character is resigned to mediocre dialog. So we have a dull, plodding script full of bad bad dialog, and it comes alive on the screen as a dull plodding movie full of bad bad dialog. Huzzah?

"Crimson Peak" is the best film directed by Guillermo del Toro. An excellent horror film in the gothic romance subgenre, which pays tribute to Hollywood films in this subgenre released in the 1940's. The script, already seen in other productions, involves more mystery, horror and romance with twists and turns in "Crimson Peak", the direction of Guillermo del Toro is tremendous, playing with love and fear. The performances of Mia Wasikowska, Jessica Chastain, Tom Hiddleston, Charlie Hunnam and Jim Beaver are refreshing. The production design is elegant, the cinematography is beautiful and gloomy at the same time, the art direction is outstanding in quality and the music score is wonderful. "Crimson Peak" is a work of art.

His latest film, "Crimson Peak" is what happens when these two worlds collide, in other words, a big budget English language horror film."Crimson Peak" is set in the late 19th century, first in New York, then in rural England. Review title: Solid Murder Mystery and Great Atmosphere Ruined by Telegraphed Plot
Review_body: I heard mixed things going into Crimson Peak. It seemed to be a love it or hate it type of film but I tried to keep my mind open. I really had no expectations, I haven't seen a lot of Guillermo Del Toro's work but the movie looked like it could be fun from the trailers. I just hoped it would be entertaining but while I admit it might not be made for my demographic, I still found it disappointing as a whole*Minor Spoilers Ahead* A very basic introduction to the plot is that when Edith is a girl, her mother dies and the night after the funeral,she is visited by her mother's ghost who delivers a simple message "beware of Crimson Peak." Then the year is 1887 Edith Cushing (Mia Wasikowska) is an aspiring writer who wants to write content along the lines of Mary Shelley but she isn't taken seriously. She has attracted the attention of her childhood friend Dr. Alan McMichael (Charlie Hunnam) who seems interested in her romantically and it is alluded that he would be the preferred choice of her father Carter Cushing (Jim Beaver) but she is oblivious and insists that she does not need to marry. But then Sir Thomas Sharpe (Tom Hiddleston) seeking funding for his clay digging machine from Carter but he is met with hostility because of his background. Despite the disapproval, Edith and Tom meet up at a party that night and their relationship begins. Lucille (Jessica Chastain) is introduced at the party as well and even though she doesn't seem to initially approve, she eventually encourages the relationship. Carter is still suspicious of Tom and even pays him to embarrass himself and Edith to dissuade him and get him to leave. But the Thomas apologizes, begs for forgiveness and proposes which Edith accepts. Then Carter dies suspiciously and Edith is whisked away to the Sharp's manor in England with Thomas and Lucille.The beginning of the movie highlights one of the outright positives of Crimson Peak, the atmosphere, the costumes and the set design are very well done. This is a point of consistent praise for Del Toro's movies and he succeeds again in Crimson Peak. The window dressing is beautiful and while there might be minor quibbles, it all feels period accurate and really helps bring you into the world that is this movie. Even when they travel to the Cushing estate, while I found the mansion to be over-the-top, it is suitably creepy and I concede it is essential to whether you will enjoy the film or not.Another positive is that I found the design of the ghosts to be interesting and scary. The mix of the CGI and the practical effects does translate well and it's definitely an asset to the film. But on the other side of that, while the ghosts look scary, how the movie decides to use them totally cuts down how well they come across. They aren't so much a malevolent force as they are present to vaguely hint to Edith's character and how they decide to get their message across I found to be really frustrating because of how unclear they are when they do. The ghosts aren't as vital to the plot as the trailers make you think as well. You could pretty easily write them out and you wouldn't miss much.I found the acting to be inconsistent. All of the main cast all range from good actors to great actors but that did not come across here. Jessica Chastain is normally a great actress but I found her character's attitude and her performance as Lucille lacking in the subtlety it needed to cultivate the mystery and I don't know if that's her acting or how the character was written. Mia Wasikowska started out strong but as her character becomes physically weaker during the movie, I felt her performance got weaker as well. I felt the actor that was closest to the intended tone was Tom Hiddleston and while I thought he did a good job, it wasn't enough to help the movie. Jim Beaver and Charlie Hunnam were both solid but Beaver isn't around long and Hunnam's performance is undercut by how lousy his character's decisions are at the endingWhich leads to my two major problems with the film, the first is how predictable the plot is. If you have seen more than a couple of horror movies, you should be able to guess point for point what is going to happen after the first 15 minutes. There could have been a good murder mystery here but within minutes of meeting certain characters or being introduced to a new plot development, I found I was always 2 or 3 steps ahead of the movie. Crimson Peak gets more and more predictable as it goes along and unfortunately because of that, I found myself getting more and more bored during the running time.Secondly, I found the character motivations to be pretty unbelievable at times. Edith is presented as an intelligent and independent young writer in the beginning but after she leaves America, she becomes really slow on the uptake. She just takes way too much at face value and it was grating how imperceptive she was about her new home and the activities of her hosts. Also at the end I couldn't believe how Hunnam's character (Dr. Alan McMichael) acted as well. Knowing what had really gone on with Thomas and Lucille, his lack of situational awareness was groan inducing.Throughout most of the film, I wasn't particularity passionate about it either way, I recognized I probably wasn't the target audience for it and just hoped it would get better. But the more it dragged on the more frustrated I got and by the climax I gave up. I enjoyed aspects of it but as the saying goes it's definitely not equal to the talent behind it.

Review title: Not Too Bad But Not The Best Film Directed By Del Toro
Review_body: From watching the trailers for Crimson Peak, I saw that it had all the elements that I usually really enjoy in a modern "ghost film"...suspense, dark & atmospheric, a sense of uneasiness, and a decent story. It had these elements (to a degree) but it also had one other element that put a dampener on the overall enjoyment of the film for me - it was slow. Slow and on the verge of actually boring me at certain moments, which is a shame because I was really looking forward to seeing this movie. I absolutely loved Mama (even though del Toro was only an executive producer for that) and Pan's Labyrinth was very enjoyable, but Crimson Peak doesn't live up to those two films.After watching it, Crimson Peak isn't really a ghost story per se but is more of a story that just happens to have ghosts in it. I know that may seem strange to say and may seem like the same thing, but it's not, and when you watch it for yourself then you'll see what I mean. In saying that, though, some of the scenes that contain the spirits are pretty eerie, especially the opening sequence and about ¾ of the way through the film with a bloody ghost coming up through the floor. I personally think that sequence was about the best one of the film. Other than that...there's not much else. I mean there's a nice sense of suspense and there is a nice atmosphere, but it's all too lacking for my taste.The whole look of the film, from the old Victorian style settings, to the cinematography & direction, were all enjoyable in their own right, but I think you can only go so far with things like that if there's nothing else to grasp your attention and keep it peaked.This IS a film worth watching, but if you're looking for - or maybe expecting - a sort of Victorian version of a modern ghost/paranormal film then you'll be sorely disappointed.Not the best del Toro film out there, but it's worth a shot.

Crimson Peak follows a young woman who falls in love with an inventor and moves away to live with him in his aging, breaking mansion. She eventually discovers ghosts inhabiting the house and begins to suspect her lover and his sister. This is one of those movies that gets better as it progresses. When the characters get to the mansion it's more interesting. It's not that tension is building or anything, nor was I ever on the edge of my seat when I watched this movie, but it's just better. It ends up amounting to, at best, an entertaining movie. However, that's all it amounts to. An entertaining movie. There really isn't a whole lot else. The horror aspects really aren't that scary or clever. It uses a lot of loud, sudden noises and relies on the creepiness of how the ghosts look too much. That not to say that there weren't at least somewhat creepy points, though. Like I said, the movie gets better as it progresses. The first half hour in particular stood out as particularly bad. It's extremely rushed, yet nothing really happens. The characters quickly fall in love, with little to no relationship development. On top of that, the two main love interests have little to no chemistry, which is what this movie seems to be relying on. The relationship wasn't developed, but if the chemistry is good then it's okay. And like I just said, they don't have much of that. By the time they moved to the mansion I simply accepted that this was their relationship and moved on, thus able to enjoy the movie more. Overall Crimson Peak is decent. It gets better as it progresses, but never amounts to anything more than entertaining. It's not exceptional or anything, just entertaining. In the end I would still recommend this movie, just don't expect another great Guillermo del Toro movie.
