There are more holes in the tale than decades old Swiss cheese and just as stale and unappealing. Rent THE SPIRAL STAIRCASE if you want shivers up and down your spine. All you'll find here is a lot of yawns as you look at your watch wondering when this mishmash will end!

Review title: Visually vibrant but plodding & predictable Victorian-era film
Review_body: As I've gotten older, I usually prefer the classic films from the 30's-60's decades. However, I subscribed to a 30-day free trial offer for Cinemax and thought this film looked intriguing, especially since I am a fan of Tom Hiddleston.First off, there was no convincing chemistry between any of the three leads, and the incestuous relationship between the brother and sister was telegraphed with their first glance. The film would have been much more effective and surprising concerning this main plot element if they had acted more like a restrained brother and sister of this particular period of time.In addition, I found the film confusing and plodding as well and the use of gory violence unnecessary. The ghosts' actions also made no sense and didn't add to the film's progression, and neither did the corpse in the "bloody" vat in the lower level. The liquid's color, though graphically vivid, looked neither like blood nor like red clay. The film's violence was just too over-the-top for me. I watch too few "horror" films nowadays and that is why I will go back to my old standards like "The Innocents" and 1944's "The Uninvited" with the handsome and charming Ray Milland. A film's horror/scare factor can be just as effective in black and white and with minimal, well-placed use of screeching and screaming. It's a shame that filmmakers (of any era) capitalize on all of the gore and violence. Give me the b/w cinematography from the first half of the 20th century any film-viewing day over the gut-wrenching violence and gore vomited on film lovers in the past few decades.My three stars are for: 1. the cinematography, 2. the costumes, and 3. the tiny dog's light-hearted presence and barking that added relief from the film's excessive, graphic violence and the irritating shrieking of the ghosts.

Review title: Hidden clue game clone... not a good one, either.
Review_body: As many people note in their reviews, the story is very banal, characters are undeveloped, cardboard, and irrational just to fit into the events, pieces and details fall off the table left and right... Yes, it's an eye candy in certain respects, music scores are good and work for all the effects intended. Visuals are great - although most of them do not serve any purpose at all, but look great, if you can accept that. Acting is very good all around, as much as it only can be with this kind of paper-thin script behind that just hardly holds any water.Hire writers from Big Fish games, they probably would do a much better job, faster and a whole lot cheaper than this. Guillermo Del Toro should have had heart and refused to direct this movie. Mind you directing was good, the movie is ... well, bad.
No one in his right mind would live in such a house. That broke the immersion for me for good.Ghosts added nothing to the plot.Not worth it.

Review title: Crimson Peak is not a horror movie!
Review_body: Crimson Peak is not a horror movie, but a Gothic romance! Don't be expecting huge jump scares, gore and screams. What it has in spades is atmosphere and general creepiness through out the movie. However... The movie is dumb! Be warned! Even having a passing familiarity with the genre, you'll be able to tell the entire plot the first act! And it will play out exactly as you'd expect! The movie is slow and it feels staggeringly dull since you know everything that will happen.Visually stunning - yes! Great performance - yes! Terrific period piece - yes! Scary - no! Interesting - no! Novel - no!I have great respect for del Toro as a filmmaker, and this is obviously a passion project, but unless you're a fan of him or the genre you'd better avoid it! Or at least approach with appropriate expectations!

Review title: One of the worst films I have ever seen
Review_body: I saw Crimson Peak last night and I was very disappointed that I wasted two hours of my life on it. I had seen the masterpiece Pan's Labyrinth and expected this to be, if not as good, at least worth seeing. It is not. The acting is pretty good (apart from the very poor Charlie Hunnam)but that is the only aspect of the film that passes muster. It starts reasonably well, albeit predictably, but then descends quickly into something akin to a poor man's Texas Chainsaw Massacre, complete with ghosts that are laughable rather than scary and a big old house with a preposterous hole in its roof. The house appears to be the main character, but it is not believable as either a real house or a Gothic horror house, because it is schlocky not scary. What possessed Chastain and the other good actors like Hiddleston to take roles in this mess is beyond me. Not good for the reputation. If this is his best current work Del Toro has lost his touch.

I only saw this film because I am a del Toro fan--Pan's Labyrinth is my favorite movie. While Crimson Peak does not come anywhere near the quality of Labyrinth in terms of the script, it still showcases del Toro's unique skill for beauty and suspense.The sets, costumes and general atmosphere are sumptuous in that signature del Toro way. The luxurious train on the heroine's robe that audibly thumps behind her as she sweeps down the staircase? Yes, please. There is a nod to all the images our minds ever conjured while reading fairy tales. The rich colors, the music, the textures all help draw us in to this world and settle us in for the story.The film is not without its flaws. There are a few glaring plot contrivances that had me groaning. There is a superficial quality to the scenes involving Thomas Sharpe's clay mining business.I was impressed with Jessica Chastain's talent for conveying two conflicting emotions at once, all playing out on her face, reminiscent of Gillian Anderson in Bleak House.

I expected much more from Guillermo del Toro, after some great dark movies in his career ("The Devil's Backbone", "Pan's Labyrinth") he went to become Hollywood mainstream and his work is downgrading massively with childish blockbusters like "Pacific Rim" and now this.If I have to point something positive about "Crimson Peak" that's the visuals, the locations, cinematography, costumes - all these were done fine. But that's ruined by a stereotypical, cheap Hollywood screenplay. The dialogue and character motivations were laughable and put there only to connect the nonexistent "twists", which can be seen by everyone who've seen more than 5 movies of the genre. At some parts of the film there were some attempts of "poetic verses" or something, which sounded so bad as the cameraman wrote them in his lunch break. The actors are not really to blame here, they did what they can with with this mediocre script.If you value your time don't waste it with this movie. Wasikowska and Hiddleston's previous Gothic film "Only Lovers Left Alive" although not perfect is far more meaningful than this. Watch it instead or just rent some of the 1970s giallo films, which "Crimson Peak" miserably tries to imitate.

I tend to give Guillermo del Toro a lot of leeway when it comes to his films, even on the rare occasion where he misses the mark. I'm afraid that would be the case with Crimson, unless you are expecting a very different kind of movie. By that, I mean, instead of expecting a Gothic ghost tale that is genuinely frightening through the use of subtlety and implied horror, the viewer should expect a visually stunning "comic book ghost story" and all that it entails.What I consider to be the benchmark for all Gothic ghost films was the original 1966 Robert Wise version of Shirley Jackson's "The Haunting of Hill House," (not the terrible Spielberg remake.) Wise successfully makes his audience cringe and jump in their seats by using only camera angles, loud noises, one very strange door, and the implication that something horrible is about to occur. While I understand the need for del Toro to make use of CGI to try to appeal to a larger audience, the movie lacked any of this type of fear at all, with the viewer being able to see every single detail of the cartoon corpses coming through the floorboards. Visually interesting, but by no means terrifying.I understand that there can never be another Haunting, or the Innocents (with Deborah Kerr), but if you remove the subtlety and realism from a Gothic ghost tale, and replace it with CGI spirits, it ends up being rather soulless.

Review title: Was I the only one rolling my eyes?
Review_body: Here's the deal: I love Guillermo del Toro. Really, I think the worlds he creates are fascinating, intricate tapestries that are a joy to try and unravel. This movie was more or less a dishrag with really pretty *super red* embroidery.What worked for me: It seemed as though we were teed up for a successful Gothic romance with the panache of Edgar Allen Poe. The costume design was extravagant, the colors rich, and it truly was an excellent cast (although to be honest I'm not a great fan of Mia W... but I can't put my finger on why, to my own discredit). Jessica Chastain was exceptional, and what's not to love about Tom Hiddleston?What didn't work for me: For all the build up to the "big reveal", the characters really never develop. And the writing. Oh god the writing. What was, I'm assuming, an attempt to draw out the more grandiose language of the era was twisted into a mixture of long-winded sentences and really, really terrible one-liners. "Sweat and regret," "...Drink...your tea..." Oof.But the two things that did it for me were the motives behind the murders... and the dog. Is it weird when people lose their marbles the moment a dog dies but don't even blink when the leading male gets a letter opener plunged right in his face at the hand of his incestuous sister? A little bit, yeah. But dogs. just. should. not. die. in. movies. It's a deal breaker for me. As for the motives... look, if Lucille and Thomas wanted to be together, they should have just run the hell away together before sending him off to get married. I get that Lucille is off her rocker, and Thomas is a malleable twit. Why not just change one of their names, run away to, you know, anywhere else in the world, and be merry? Why marry Thomas off for money only to kill the new wife so they can barely afford to keep running a decrepit old house that they can't stand, trying to run a business that's clearly failing? "But Ellen," you say. "It's more complicated than that," you say. "Think about The Fall of the House of Usher!!", you say. If it's supposed to be more complicated than a crappy business model and a crazy woman's penchant for stabbing people, then it really shouldn't have been so easy to predict about 80% of the plot fifteen minutes in.I guess what I'm trying to say is, I really wanted to like this movie. It all seemed like a recipe for del Toro's earlier genius. The Devil's Backbone meets The Fall of the House of Usher meets Jane Eyre. What I got out of it was more akin to a less interesting Jane Eyre meets anything by Baz Luhrmann meets that time George Lucas thought he could write a screenplay, and we all sighed. Sadly, I would not recommend.

Being brought up with the 'old time' B&W ghost/horror movie era I unfortunately could only give Crimson Peak, a rating of 2.I found the movie had fallen into the modern trend of excessive use of special digital effects, which made attempts at horror, gore and the props, all way overdone. A case in point was the "excessively dark and oppressive house", the rather vague and meaningless "ghosts" that regularly popped up, and the lengthy "stabbing and slashing" scene by a small but confusing variety of people with a variety of objects, near the end. This became all quite tedious and had the effect of 'a numbing out' of the senses. The story was also somewhat disjointed and lacked depth.There was little of the subtlety of movies of a bygone era when there was less reliance on computer graphics and gore, and more effort put into story line and build up of suspense. It has little of the "fear quality" that can be found in B&W movies such as "The Young Innocents," "Psycho" etc and even color such as "Black Christmas," "The Shining" and the excellent, "The Others"Take a look at some of these and you will hopefully 'see' what I mean.

At first I was a bit disappointed but then I started thinking about the plot and came to realize that it's kind of perfect.What caught my attention is the beautifully written dialog and the impeccable diction of the actors. I loved the word choice and style as well as the art of speaking.Everything fell into place, set design, costumes and characters. I must say I didn't expect a love story thus the reason why I was initially disappointed. But then again I have no idea why I was waiting for a something more sinister. Maybe the trailer gave me a bad impression... Maybe the marketing for this movie was simply wrong. Doesn't matter.Now I believe that the beginning of the movie sets the storyline and also predicts the ending. Edith Cushing (Mia Wasikowska) is an aspiring author. Her "ghost" story is criticized for not being about love and her career choice is ridiculed by other women comparing her to Jane Austin. Yet Edith sees herself more as a widow like Mary Shelley rather than a spinster. And there you go... A handsome young man, known as Sir Thomas Sharpe (Tom Hiddleston) appears and her "ghost" story suddenly changes to a love story. The reason I keep using quotation marks for the word ghost is because it's really not a ghost story. The ghosts are a metaphor for the past (just like Edith herself explains it).Knowing Guillermo del Toro's work, this does make sense. In the end, I really liked the movie.

A great scenario...
A wonderful artwork of baroque and gothic symbols..and love, romance and intrigue.

Crimson Peak is a real masterpiece. Furthermore, I dare to claim that it is the best movie I've seen in the past five years. The movie is very luxurious, but special effects are strictly confined to the screenplay. Although the main story is a cliché, the screenplay itself is amazingly well written with no logical pitfalls, which is a very rare case in the modern film industry. There is space for some minor tweaks, to make it a bit more realistic, but it would certainly spoil a lyrical thread of the movie. Guillermo del Toro extremely well balances between reality and fiction, love story and brutality, intelligence and madness. All characters are very complex and quite realistic. Their psychological profiles are one of the many virtues of this extraordinary movie. It is very hard to convey the impression imposed by the move; it is something that has to be experienced.

Some people have hyped this movie hard, in no small part because it's been a while since del Toro has done a genuinely scary movie. Unfortunately, the final result is disappointing and underwhelming. It focuses on a young girl who has always had an affinity for supernatural, and following her father's death (don't strain yourself too hard on the killer), she decides to leave everything behind and go to England with her new lover/washed-up aristocrat.The beginning is interesting enough, but the move drags on for too long, and it offers us very little in return. You might expect some sort of haunted house setup, but what you'll actually get is mostly a boring "whodunit" drama between three people in the middle of nowhere. And the final twist is just underwhelming because by the time it happens you'll either figure it out on your own or just not care about it anymore.It's a shame that such a stellar cast of actors (shout-out to Supernatural fans here) got involved in this, considering that this had a lot of potential, but eventually simply failed to deliver. The costumes and photography are really good, and along with good acting probably the saving points for this movie. If you intend to watch this, don't expect another Pan's Labyrinth, because that's now what you'll get.

Great story for all Poe-like horror lovers. A movie, that is based on tension rather than on modern effects. Beautiful Gothic atmosphere and color symbolism. If you enjoy old horror stories from the turn of the twentieth century, this is perfect for you.Del Toro chose his actors carefully. Acting is great, as well as costumes and sets. The key to understand this movie is to get to know the roots of modern horror. Do not compare it with modern movies. Compare it with classic horror books.It was great to find a modern tribute to classic horror stories and authors. If you know what to expect, it will definitely not disappoint you.

Review title: A great romance and a decent horror
Review_body: Excellent cinematography and costume, I was surprised this movie costs only 55m$ dollar.The whole movie is creepy but not many jump scares. However, for a romantic drama, this is scary enough.The cast is amazing, Tom H, Mia W, Jessica C all did remarkably good job.The sex scene is a little bit funny, silly to be more exact.The first part of the movie is too cheesy, but it gets more complicated and intense over time.Overall, this movie is OK. It's engrossing and interesting, I highly recommend it.

Starts slow.. but stick with it and you'll see a great movie. Truly did not deserve the hate it got by critics. If you want a really scary movie.. this is not it. But it you want a beautiful gothic masterpiece with scary undertones you've got it. Tom Hiddleston and Jessica Chastain are amazing. 10/10.

Being a fan of Guillermo del Toro, I was very much looking forward to seeing Crimson Peak and was over the moon when I won passes to an advanced screening. I'll cut to the chase. Visually, the piece was beautiful. Gothic, Victorian costumes and sets...the use of color was stunning. I really loved the cinematography for the most part. Aside from the visuals, the casting was off. I don't really care for Mia Wasikowska, but her acting, particularly in one scene, was dreadful. I honestly do not understand how she continues to land leading roles such as her character "Edith." Charlie Hunnam was miscast as well. Tom Hiddleston and Jessica Chastain were great, however. Part of the writing of the dialogue is to blame, but I did enjoy the story, although I did predict the (MAJOR SPOILER) "Flowers in the Attic" twist towards the end. Overall, the whole thing was underwhelming and it felt like I had sat through a Gothic soap opera with a few spooks thrown in. I'm still not sure what was scarier, the acting or the ghosts.

Review title: So predictable it was a waste of two hours.
Review_body: I had the chance to see this at a movie preview and regret going.Unfortunately, the story is one that is told again and again and is so predictable its laughable.There are major flaws (a red rubber ball for a dog which was not available in that time period, blood that disappears from pillows and so on) that do not help the movie in any way.I will say that visually it is stunning. The CGI was mostly on point as well.Unfortunately, each of the actors look as though they are forcing every scene and every line.Not worth seeing in theaters. If you really want to see it wait until it is released on Blu-ray or DVD.

What really stayed with me after this movie was how feelings of anger, fear, or even revenge resulting from the experience of traumatic and painful events in life when held on to and not resolved, trap people in that very moment of trauma and pain and keeps them from letting those feelings go and moving on to peace in the future. What better metaphor then ghosts to convey this in the movie. Spirits that should have moved on to peace, are instead deteriorating in a world of past traumas and pain. But, the ghosts are not the only ones. The house itself and its inhabitants are also trapped in such a fate in Crimson Peak. As they fight to continue to remain in the pain of the past, or break free to live in the future their feelings of anger, fear, love, and hate cause them to do monstrous things to each other.Fans of Gothic romance, the lead actors, and the visual beauty of the director's other films will enjoy this movie.

Review title: Wonderfully presented fun with some darker undertones
Review_body: OK now Crimson Peak is NOT a movie for all ages or sensibilities but it is thrilling with a good goosebump factor and plenty of treats this Halloween.It opens with a wonderful voice over setting up the theme very well, the opening scene got my goosebumps going. The storyline is impressive, grand almost, a love story, wrapped up in a ghost / horror story with a dark edge and some good twists and turns. Not overly gory but there is murder and mayhem, and the ghouls are excellent.The storyline moves along well not too fast but at a good clip. I had an issue with the main location it was a bit of stretch for me but a lot of people will probably enjoy it. Outstanding acting matched some exceptionally well written characters who were so believable they drew me in completely. The love is both darker lustier and sweeter more innocent, not overly graphic but certainly erotic. The main characters faced believable struggles which enable me to really buy into them and a reasonable fight scene.Overall an excellent date movie this Halloween the girls can get their eye candy with Hiddleston and the guys can savor the sweet Mia Wasikowska.

Del Toro never disappoints in crafting beautiful, extravagant sets for his movies. The problem is the actual story of 'Crimson Peak' is not very interesting - even when looked at as a Gothic romance.Let's start with the ghosts; These tortured spirits, roaming a massive decaying castle at night, mysterious and gory. They should evoke fear. The problem is, and this is the same problem I had with Mama, is that the ghosts appear so frequently, in the same exact way every time, that you get used to their presence. They are clearly made to be nonthreatening to the audience, but the main character doesn't understand this. It's hard to use this as a critique because Del Toro has stated the movie isn't a horror, but it's frustrating all the same.While on the topic of the genre, which is Gothic romance, there is a severe lack of romance in this movie. The "gothic" is covered extensively via Allerdale Hall, images of Wasikowska wandering with the dark halls with candlelight, the brilliant blood-red clay which seeps its color into the bright white snow. Even with all this imagery, there is no romance to support it. Hiddleston and Wasikowska have no chemistry. From the very first time you see Hiddleston he looks sinister and unloving and his demeanor never changes until maybe the final moments.Though Hiddleston fails as a romantic protagonist, his sister played by Jessica Chastain was marvelous. She was by far the most interesting character.'Crimson Peak', with its' various plot problems, was sometimes dull to watch, sometimes spectacular. The scenes inside Allerdale Hall, along with the excellent final act, somewhat make up for the weak central romance, but it is overall a slightly disappointing effort from Del Toro.

Review title: Not so good, a mediocre movie, is actually a drama and romantic movie + a little suspense
Review_body: I will be short. Let's begin with the bad scenes from this movie. The first half of the movie is so boring. You will be disappointed for sure. Now the end of the movie is so stupid, ) didn't enjoy it, ) enjoyed only the part that Mia was safe in the end. And also the way he died like a fool, when he could save Mia, instead of dying for nothing and how Mia has survived from that big falling, without any leg/hand ruptured, in real life she was in coma already.. then the final fight between the 2 women, really sucks,was not realistic and could be better. But the movie has a few scary/suspense scenes and also Mia W. is looking and is acting perfect. The castle was spooky with a lot of mysteries. Overall let's say 5/10, Mia made the movie watchable.

Review title: if you are going to watch it expecting to watch a horror movie don't go
Review_body: I don't know who ranked this movie under the Genre HORROR! !!! I Gave it 1 star & i'm still feel like i gave it to much! for Real Horror fans that movie was garbage but if you are into Romantic & Crime and this type of movies that is something you will like but the trailer was sick and showed some Horror it was ranked as a horror movie so i decided to watch it! but then i felt i wasted 2 hours of my life watching that movie! it's a two faced movie. the effects were good it would have made a really good Horror movie but then the blew it up after the 20th minute. i just think it's overrated movie because of the cast & the good trailer they made!

She will stab you in the face.First of all, I'd like to congratulate Del Toro on yet another masterpiece. This outstanding film, which has incorrectly been promoted as 'horror', is one of the best I have ever seen. Finally a film that's not scary for all the things you do see, but scary for all the things you do not see.Young, innocent, curious Edith Cushing falls in love with handsome, dark, mysterious stranger Sir Thomas Sharpe, and it is evident they are made for each other. His sister, Lady Lucille Sharpe, is an enigma. She's cold, distant, yet so close and warm-hearted around Thomas.Now, allow me to clear up the confusion about the 'horror' thing. It's definitely not a horror film. It's a Gothic romance; it does have elements of the supernatural, but they do not determine the plot. In this case, they are very important, but they are a foreboding. The romance part is obvious: the innocent girl, the dark stranger, his mysterious sister. Fun fact: the film contains loads and loads of metonymy; the most important one being the cold, decayed house, sinking in red clay, obviously resembling the two Sharpe's relationship. Once you're home and you think this film over and over again, you will find more and more metonymy, beautifully hidden in the background.'Crimson Peak' is romantic, a bit scary, but most of all, a must-see for all.

When I first saw previews for this movie I was super excited and then I read the reviews online and thought this movie might be worth giving a shot. This movie should have been rated T for terrible. The entire movie was a huge let down. The movie's imagery was beautiful and visually stunning, however the long drawn out story line, repetitiveness, one dimensional characters, and the overall plot unlike the imagery was not enough to capture your attention. Many action parts were uneventful and left you unfulfilled and wanting more. To be honest I was shocked this movie was even rated R as I felt I was watching a PG13 movie at best. The overall theme was boring and not at all a horror/ or a fantasy movie. The previews made it look so great unfortunately this movie did not deliver. Honestly unless you can watch this movie for free I wouldn't even spend 1.50 or whatever it cost at Redbox.

Review title: Disappointing with a few redeeming qualities
Review_body: I'm a huge fan of del Toro ever since Pan's Labyrinth and with such a great cast, I had high hopes for this movie. Seeing it yesterday at a midnight Halloween screening, I was severely disappointed.To be fair and thorough, I will start with the few things I liked about this movie and then get to everything that went wrong.+ The casting is fitting and most of the actors play really well. Particularly Wasikowska does a great job, carrying every emotion in her face without overacting or losing her grace. Hiddleston is as good as usual. The rest of the cast is solid at least, but sometimes its hard to tell if the the characters or the actors are that shallow.+ This movie got style. The costumes are awesome, the scenery is amazing. Down to the make-up and hair-style, everything is superb. It even got unique element with the red clay. If you're happy just seeing great actors in authentic looking Gothic attire, running around in a spectacular old mansion with butterflies everywhere, you might actually enjoy this movie. My girlfriend did.The first big setback is the characters being implausible, one- dimensional and really stupid. It starts off so well, with Wasikoswska portraying this young, independent, smart writer with Mary Shelly as an idol. What a promising character! Turns out she is just a simple girl ready to submit fully to the first charismatic man paying her any attention. Another example is when someone comes to the rescue, confronts the evil guy, and then just turns his back to them to leave. I mean, even in slasher movies they take a baseball bat or golf club or something to defend themselves. This whole movie would have turned out differently if any of the characters would have had a golf club instead of just, you know, expecting the evil to guys to not do evil things after turning their backs to them. Duh.The special effects are technically mediocre at best. But even worse, they are completely uninspired. It's just translucent skeletons. Sometimes with clay on the bones. That's it. You come to expect great monster design from del Toro after movies like Pan's Labyrinth or Hellboy. Not in this one, boys. Just stupid, boring, old skeletons. Meh.Very graphic gore and violence, that seems totally out of place and never really hits home. I watch a lot of gore movies, so graphic violence is no problem to me. But in this movie, it doesn't work, because it doesn't feel embedded. At one point, you see a head smashed into a sink repeatedly, über-brutally. It really doesn't fit with the more graceful style of the rest of the movie. And not in a good way, like the sudden violence in Pan's Labyrinth that turns your stomach. This is just randomly mixed in B-movie gore.It's not creepy. I mean, this is supposed to be a horror movie, I thought. But it doesn't manage to build up creep or even just setup nice shock effects. The style I praised before is partly responsible: the scenery is too be pretty and stylized to actually be scary. The movie is also very bright, no dim lights anywhere. And the ghosts, well, as I said, boring old skeletons. Nothing new or creepy from this side.The plot is the worst part of the movie. It is utterly predictable and based on lazy writing and the stupidity of the main characters. You know the good guys and bad guys in the first 15 minutes and can pretty much guess what comes next at any second. The ghosts are completely superfluous for the story. Nothing really would have changed by keeping them out, all they do is prophecy bad things and try (and fail) to be scary. The clay mines had so much potential for plot and scares, but they used none of it. There are no twists, no character development, no nothing. Not the least bit of originality. Once the movie ends, you just feel bored and empty.To sum it up, if you want to watch this movie because you are fan of Pan's Labyrinth or other work of del Toro comparable this, don't go in this one. If you are looking for a cool ghost movie with a few scares and original character design, don't go in this one. If you just want to see a stylish movie with at least as plausible and smart as Hollywood action flick, still don't go in this one.If you don't care at all about plots or ghosts. If you just want to enjoy good actors in great mask with awesome costumes, playing before in a fantastic scenery, then you should watch this. If you don't mind unexpected gore and look forward to Mr. Hiddleston's exposed butt, then you should watch this. If you liked the Devil's Backbone, del Toros' other ghost movie that is very similar to this one, then you should definitely go for it.Just know what to expect, so you won't be as disappointed as I was.

Review title: I wish I could give it 0 star
Review_body: Worst movie .. don't watch fully crap ... Never watch it

Review title: Visually recognizable as Del Toro, other than that, not so good.
Review_body: Watched this last night and I must say, I'm disappointed. Storyline was weak at best, and there was a lot of plot holes. Visually I did like the house, but the cgi ghosts were awful. I haven't read the book so I don't know how much of it is in this movie but it did not live up to the hype at all. The thing that bothered me the most was the love story. It seemed to have been created out of thin air. I mean they fell deeply in love within hours without saying more than a few words to each other?! Sure it's possible but it just didn't seem believable at all. Also, the main character didn't seem to mind the gigantic hole in the ceiling of the house, or that it was sinking into the ground, she just moved right in. Sorry if my English is bad, it's my first review and it's not my native language.

This movie was originally marketed as a horror film which is why I believe it gets overlooked, it's not really a horror at all! This is a spooky gothic romance that is utterly gorgeous visually and acting wise.
This movie does have some graphic violence but it's not really ever 'scary' in my opinion.
I hope one day this movie gets more recognition and becomes a gothic romance classic!

Review title: Watched for school, watched again for myself
Review_body: I personally loved this movie. I had to choose a movie from the horror genre, which wasn't my thing, and a friend recommended Crimson Peak. It miraculously held my attention throughout the whole thing (a miracle on it's own since I'm ADHD), and had my heart racing several times. The cast did an amazing job, and the visuals were awe-inspiring. I watched it twice in one day, and enjoyed it just as much the second time around. Definitely one of my new favourites. There, admittedly, were some plot holes, such as Edith's mother warning her, and how easy it was to tell the "good guys" from the "bad guys" but all in all, I loved it.

Review title: Sumptuous visuals from Mexican director del Toro
Review_body: Gorgeous film & great story. I take issue with one other person's review: Guillermo del Toro is NOT Spanish. He is Mexican, from Guadalajara, Jalisco.

Review title: A slow burn for most, but a great in-depth story
Review_body:
The Short
Story: Story is exceptional with plenty of intrigue, suspense, and many factors that keep one interested and invested as to what may happen next.Characters: Acting allowed for the characters to have a life of their own and be completely believable as people.Effects: Visual effects and designs definitely cemented belief in the setting and situations, extremely well done visuals and sets.Lighting: Use of scene-based lighting rather than pure studio lighting is present in most scenes, allowing for added immersion.Sound Design: Sounds do not seem out of place and further add to immersion with their well-done designs.Themes: Set pieces, props, and clothing seem to be quite era-appropriate, once again allowing for a pleasant immersive experience.Expanded (no spoilers)
Though a simple story in premise with only a few unique parts to it, the story elements do not overstay their welcome, or flesh out to become something entirely different from what they were initially established as.The journey that our main characters go through feels natural and enjoyable, having them confront several stopping forces and through a combination of subtle to large changes, evolve as characters. Revolving primarily around three characters for most of the central plot means that there isn't a lot of room to flesh things out under ordinary circumstances, but with the well thought out plot, the characters are able to work off of each other and allows for a lot of small developments within them, going on to further breathe life into the world around them.Characters are established in various levels at the beginning, giving us enough to work with for some, and plenty with others. Though as the movie unfolds, more is learned about all of the characters, allowing for better understanding of what has led to them being the way that they are now, with some more of the twists and secret information being kept until very close to the ending sequence of the movie.Set across an interesting time in which harsh conditions and approval was of utmost importance, the movie manages to handle these themes competently and even manages to play around with them a little, almost leaving them as a backdrop to the overall concept of the movie without forgetting them and making sure that the audience feels connected to the characters.Lighting greatly enhances the immersion in this movie as in several scenes the lighting excels at creating atmosphere, reflecting character personalities, what they bring to the table, and most importantly, allowing a scene to feel correct with depth and lighting style.Extra (spoilers)
Filled to the brim with symbology right from the start, Edith Cushing (Mia Wasikowska) is plagued with the ability to see ghosts, including that of her own mother, which haunts her, though as we come to learn rather quickly, this is not a malicious spirit, and is benevolent and guiding, something shared by the other ghosts presented in the film.Suspense is successfully built up after the arrival of Thomas Sharpe (Tom Hiddlestone) and Lucille Sharpe (Jessica Chastain) when they have a short but crucial interaction with Edith's father, Carter Crushing (Jim Beaver). We quickly learn that all is not as it seems, though not quite at the depth revealed as the story continues.Edith is torn between two worlds from the very start, wanting to write about ghosts as an author, and conforming to the societal norm. Through that inner turmoil reflects the outside world she is living in, when she begins to fall in love with Thomas Sharpe, she has a chance at escaping all that her life has become and taking charge. However, her father puts a stop to that when he feels that something is not quite right between Edith and Thomas, being suspicious of him from before when mentioning the amount of times Thomas has reached out for help across various places.Edith eventually ends up going to Crimson Peak, unaware of its name at that time, previously having been advised from deceased mother to "Beware of the Crimson Peak".A large portion of the movie takes place within the house in Crimson Peak, where Lucille offers Edith some tea on a few occasions, we learn rather quickly to believe that something isn't right with the tea, and it is later revealed to be poisoned, a great display of Lucille's character. Showing that she is subtle in the way she deals with her problems but hinting that her toxicity is a deep flaw.Edith, slowly dying from the poison would begin to suspect the happenings at Crimson Peak with the interference and guidance of a few spirits, including that of Lucille and Thomas's mother.Thomas and Lucille plan to have Edith die once she has signed off a transfer deed, granting the Sharpes ownership over her estate, not longer having need of her afterwards.During this time, we learn of Thomas's multiple marriages and the fact that Lucille had been in a mental institution, furthering the "something isn't right" feeling.Up until around three quarters in to the movie, Thomas has been all for Lucille's plan and excited to go about this prospect once again, though now starts to feel suffocated by her presence in his life, wanting to leave that life all behind and start anew, having actually fallen in love with Edith. This advances Thomas's character and serves as a strong growth point for his character, showing a divide between the once perfect sibling couple. Lucille is unable to accept this information, and once Thomas burns the signed papers, Lucille lets her jealousy take control, killing her brother in a blind rage.With the final confrontation taking place outside of the house, Edith fights off Lucille, aided by the ghost of Thomas. Edith tells Lucille to turn around to look at her brother, Lucille doing so. Upon seeing the ghost of her brother, it is clear that her character has developed in her final moments. Having had either no guilt, or such little guilt over her previous murders, she was not able to see the ghosts within the house. Seeing the ghost of her brother shows that there is a guilt weighing on her now that was once not present, this being all Edith needed to get a final blow on Lucille, freeing herself from that nightmare.Returning to the beginning of the movie, it shows that a core plot point is that you never escape the ghosts of your past, only ignore for so long until they manifest, and you are unable to escape what has happened. Though this is portrayed differently with Edith and Lucille. Edith is able to learn from these past incidents and ghosts, allowing for her to survive where they had not, accepting the past and trying for a better future, whereas with Lucille, she is unable to move on from the past and these ghosts end up serving as a sign that her past has caught up to her, finally being too much for her to escape from.Overall the movie is extremely well directed, written, lit, designed, and acted out. The concept though simple was well executed and made for an entertaining and informative movie that I would highly recommend.

The plot is predictable. The suspense is weak. The CGI ghosts and jump scares are lame. And any actual romance, drama, or tragedy are nonexistent. The premise and sets had so much promise that this film utterly failed to deliver on. I hung in there hoping that it might redeem itself in a "so bad it's good" b-movie kind of way, but nope... this is just boring, a complete misuse of the gothic.

After watching Loki on Disney Plus I found myself on a Hiddlebinge (and who can blame me). I stumbled across Crimson Peak, a 2015 Gothic Horror/Romance starring my favorite British heart throb, Mia Wasikowska, and JESSICA FRIGGEN CHASTAIN?? Also you know no big deal but directed by Guillermo Del Toro!!! (I was also very pleased to see Jim Beaver after my supernatural days)This has become my favorite film of all time. Aside from an A+ cast this movie had so much going for it. Period drama, fantastic score, a downright creepy and spooky setting, gorgeous costumes, a heart wrenching romance, and twists at every corner. Yes the plot could be considered lack luster but its not meant to be some life changing experience. Its a spooky scary movie about a spooky scary house with a cast that gives it their all.Crimson Peak is a masterpiece and I will never grow sick of singing its praises. If you haven't seen it, Go watch it now. And If you have seen it and you're a fellow movie enthusiast like me watch all the documentaries and YouTube essays about this movie. It is evident so much love went into it and every fiber of this film is powerful and stunning.It made me cry you guys. I'm not a crier. I sobbed. Absolutely stunning. Guillermo never ceases to amaze me.
The acting is very good, the costumes and set feel authentic. A refreshingly good scary movie.

Tedious and illogical horror film, unimaginative special effects, and unattractive and dull leads.The design of the stately home was interesting, the roof allowing snow to fall into the building was charming but was wishing for the end by the half-way mark.There are many better versions of this story, i.e. Gaslight, and any number of related plots from British horror films of the 60's and 70's.Is this the inevitable fate of European auteur in Hollywood, low brow pretentiousness? Strangely this film was warmly greeted by the critics, like the new stars wars film.Payola for the 21st century, anyone?

I have eagerly been awaiting Crimson Peak for a long time now. It was pretty much my most highly anticipated movie of the year. I love Guillermo Del Toro and think that's Pan's Labyrinth is one of the best movies ever made. And Crimson Peak was very good. Not as amazing as Pan's Labyrinth and not as scary as the trailer makes it seem, but definitely worth seeing. The costumes and makeup were fabulous and the set design, and cinematography were gorgeous and the casting was great. The violence and gore and the whole kind of fairytale atmosphere of the film were signature del Toro. The violence was quite graphic in some instances, such as a character's head being repeatedly bashed, crushing their skull and leaving their face pretty much in recognizable. Definitely worth seeing but I just wish it had been scarier. I'd give it a 7.5, maybe 8 out of 10.

A gorgeous looking film, but with an incredibly slow pace and plot. There is little about it that could classify it as a horror movie and little that would make it a thriller. Everything that happens is easily predicted well before it occurs on screen and nothing happens nearly as fast as it should. The characters are bland and unoriginal, as are the actors performance, but there is simply nothing for them to work with.At no point was I scared or startled or impressed, but rather found myself wondering if it was ever going to get interesting. The running commentary I had with my sister, with whom I saw the film, was far more entertaining than anything on the screen.The four rating I give this movie is for visuals alone, as nothing else about this movie is worth mentioning.
Victorian gothic at its best and simply gorgeous. Del Toro understands Victorian horror and ghost stories. Hiddleston charms and the house is the centerpiece.

This may not be the kind of movie that appeals to the widest audience but I simply adored it. It is even better on the second viewing because some of the dialogue that seems a bit stilted at first (Let's go to the post office!) hits home when you realize Lucille is calling the shots and Thomas is seeking her permission. (I don't think I'm in spoiler territory. This is as generic as I can make it.) Crimson Peak was scary enough for my taste, has the lushest cinematography I've seen in a while, and fantastic performances. Hiddleston and Chastain are heartbreaking. There's also more story at work than film critics are giving this movie credit for.

Review title: Worst movie I have ever watched
Review_body: This was a terrible movie! There was absolutely nothing redeeming about it. The character makes the most idiotic counter-intuitive decisions from almost the beginning and continues receiving clues and hard evidence and *WITH FULL ACKNOWLEDGEMENT* of these facts within the movie of everything bad that is happening she still continues on and not only doesn't do anything at all to prevent it but she keeps on going about as if nothing is happening. This is literally the stupidest thing I have ever seen and I created an IMDb account because it was so irritating to watch. It made me want to scream and the ONLY reason I continued watching was because I actually starting to root for the "evil" and hoped it would turn into one of those flicks where there is no redemption and in the end the lead is buried and forgotten. I can only hope the directors wife or mother scream at him for making this pile of steaming garbage.

Review title: After a few years , it still holds up
Review_body: This is a stunning visual feast, with the tiniest of details finished to perfection. Costuming, architecture, lighting...it makes me wanna kiss Guillermo del Toro right on the face. The story does slow at the end, but spend your downtime looking at the backgrounds, and enjoy what's unfolding to its inevitable gothic conclusion. Oh yes...and the moral of the story? ALWAYS listen to your mother.

Review title: Extremely Disappointing Gothic Film from the Amazing Del Toro
Review_body: 2 stars are for the beauty, detailed beautiful fashion, and haunting screen shots in the film. One more star for Guillermo del Toro ---because I love him. That said, there isn't much in this film for us to go on. Crimson Peak is neither romance nor a ghost story. It treks upon a betrayal drama with a inkling of 'supposed' romance but none of the relationships stand out significantly to our disappointment.A beautiful young wealthy American woman name Edith (played by Mia Wasikowska) falls for a tall dark Handsome British Baronet Thomas Sharpe ( played by Tom Hiddleston) and moves to England with him after her father was mysteriously murdered, ghosts appear and seems to haunt her in the decapitating house of Thomas and his sister Lucia (Jessica Chastain) is cold, harboring resentment to everyone, especially to Edith. Portrayed as interesting, quick witted and perceptive in the first 40 minutes, Edith quickly becomes fearful, and delusional in the house---- Ghosts appear but they did little to explain the story, the twist quickly comes when Edith realizes through a series of investigation at night-- that Lucia and Thomas were a scheme. Thomas would marry rich women to get their money to invest in his inventions and Lucia murders the wives them by poisoning their tea. Of course the implied love story here is that Thomas has fallen for Edith, he woos her in America and marries her and although scheming her, he does make love to her after a night out of the house when they got snowed in at the post office, even declaring she is not the 'others' (other wives he had schemed). But the romance is neither believable nor substantial when he declares he loves her near end of movie. Edith soon finds out Thomas and Lucia were having an incestual relationship, discovering them having sex after an apparition leads her to Lucia's room; the declaration of love on Thomas's part later in film comes off as weak and entirely unbelievable. Lucia throws Edith off the balcony when Edith found them and she wakes up in a chair, saved by Dr. Alan McMichael (Edith's friend from America who came to save her; played by Charlie Hunnam ). Ending unravels in a mess, Lucia killing Thomas over his apparent love for Edith and the madwoman chasing Edith around in the snow outside, when Thomas's ghost appear, distracting the guilt ridden Lucia for a split second thus allowing Edith to snap Lucia's head with a shovel. Edith saves Dr. McMichael and they walk out into the snow away from Crimson Peak.The ghosts---- in the film were used only when 'necessarily' thus even the supernatural aspect of the film felt cheap. The romance between Edith and Thomas hardly exist and exasperated the ending where he declared her love while there was no significant or interaction in film to show proof of that. There was very little chemistry among the actors and that is proof among Hiddleston's portrayal of Thomas and Chastain's portrayal of Lucia: although in a incestual relationship born out of a childhood bonding from their isolation from the outside world and parental abuse, it was came off as forced and off putting. Overall plot to the film was weak, with very little character development, there was even a intriguing short dialogue where Edith explains to Thomas that characters in books can freely chose who they can be , further implying Thomas had a decision in his part of scheme and can change but that neither explored or investigated later in film. However Hiddleston's performance as Thomas is convincing and outstanding, at times convincing us of Thomas's humanity but unfortunately his character experiences no true revelation of his own. Viewers can see he is a mere lover/puppeteer to Lucia and he dies expectedly so. He cowardly saves Dr. Alan McMichaelson but from second half of the movie, falls into a secondary character. Neither could he save himself; or in this manner, his supposed romantic interest : Edith. Lucia however, quickly become a central character in the film, unveiling her evil motivations, exercising sexual and maternal possessive role over Thomas, and confessing to Edith of her murders including Edith's father. The beautiful bright Edith portrayed by Mia was interesting in first portion of film but quickly falls wayside when half of second movie was her running around in dark halls of Crimson Peak, delusional and confused----much like the viewers. She becomes highly reactive and immature, losing our interest as viewers to trust that our narrative character could change the current situation or respond in a coherent manner.Viewers within first hour of movie will waiting --anticpiating-- for Del Toro's master storytelling: will it be a horror film full of ghosts, or rather a mystery/crime period piece? A true Gothic love story with strong romantic lead characters? Unfortunately It was none of those.Although Del Toro's other Gothic fairytale Pan's Labyrinth was dark, mysterious , scary, fantastical, violent and beautiful, Del Toro was able to bring to it such a depth of humanity with surprisingly moments full of joy, love, compassion and even innocent wonder ---all which were deeply lacking in Crimson Peaks. Crimson Peaks simply put-----is lifeless, much like the ghosts haunting the halls of Baronet Thomas Sharpe's mansion.

Review title: Perfect Halloween movie, great atmosphere, loved it!
Review_body: For those who don't fancy horror, don't worry, if there's something I don't watch a lot it's horror. This movie however is not the cheap 'booing-accompanied-by-sudden-loud-noise' kinda story. The setup, the drop by drop delivery of the mystery, and the portraying of ghosts (yes, there are ghosts but no spoiler here because we know that after the first sentence of the movie; I would say its not a ghost story, it's more of a story with ghosts in it but that will make sense only when you watch the movie) all part of a plan of a great director who brought us 'Pan's labyrinth'. Visually often the 'you can't take your eyes off of it' kind of creepy. Mixed with brilliant game with the lighting and such beautiful and vivid colors that come through even the darkest corridors.Sensing the big secret behind the main characters is not a big deal, actually my version of the background halfway into the film turned out to be better (or just more creepy...) than the actual one. It's only partly about secrets.The set was exactly what it was supposed to be. I loved the costumes, loved the way people were phrasing sentences, and loved the whole set. But the big house the second half of the movie focused on, was just the perfect place to get scared. Every time the mansion was on the screen I felt that I was mostly amazed and a little frightened somehow (pretty much what one would expect watching a Tim Burton movie) but - weirdly - feeling every single time a little bit more impressed by the measures of it, by the beauty it once may have had. And every time I saw the defects of the house my disgust started turning into 'Wow how cool is that!' As for the faint-hearted who don't like the sight of inner organs and blood, on a list of 1-10 (where 10 represents Elm street amount of blood mixed with Tarantino's detailed sound effects and 1 stands for... say, SpongeBob...,) I'd give it a 6 or 7 because of the finale of the movie. And for the constant disgusted faces you'll make.All in all: quite the perfect movie to kick start your Halloween mood, just a week before it.

Review title: Guillermo Del Toro, come on man.
Review_body: The worst Guillermo Del Toro movie I've ever seen. As usual I loved the way it looked, but the story and characters were so uninteresting I wanted to turn it off nearly every scene. I'm not sure who would have been scared or even remotely freaked out by this movie. The cgi ghosts are cool looking, but not creepy or scary at all. I think the best scene in the movie was when the father got his face smashed on the sink and the bloody water is going everywhere. Besides the cool visuals everyone's dialogue made me roll my eyes. I think there was a story at some point, but it wasn't interesting enough for me to pay complete attention.

Review title: This movie belongs on Netflix, but not in the theaters.
Review_body: Don't expect to be scared during this movie.. at all. The plot was simple, boring, and predictable and the casting/acting seemed off. Some of the scenery was nice, but that's not going to make a terrible movie that much better. Everyone with me felt the same way and I even heard others in the theater exclaim: "that movie sucked" afterward; one couple even walked out three-quarters of the way through it. It was both surprising and disappointing, because I've enjoyed most other Guillermo del Toro films. Do yourself a favor and pass on this movie, at least for now. This movie belongs on Netflix, but not in the theaters.

Not scary, poor acting (with the obvious exception of Jessica), awful plot and saw most if it coming miles away. The only part it made me frightened was because I was watching a recorded box version and when it finished and I turned it to direct TV it was starting again.

I thought CRIMSON PEAK was a near perfect example of traditional Gothic storytelling. Even if (like me) you aren't a fan of the genre, I think you'll be able to appreciate its quality. Also, the acting was fantastic. I have two quibbles:1. I thought the ghosts were . . . not very scary. Their hands were creepy as hell, and catching glimpses of them guttering down hallways was scary, but once you got a good luck at their faces, they were liked evil Wallace and Gromits, with the oversized, misshapen Día de Muertos skulls. Plus that shade of red reminds me of over-lacquered knickknacks at Chinese restaurants.2. Tom Hiddleston's character was kind of beta, and I infinitely prefer alphas. BUT. That's an issue of personal preference.

I agree with all the reviews about the exquisite setting, costumes, the magnificent old rundown mansion that is Aderllel Hall. What I really want to talk about here though is the Plot of the movie, and beware there are so many spoilers in this it is probably best to read it if you have watched the movie or have no intention to watch it, or do not mind find out about the entire story before watching it.I had been following Crimson Peak from when the trailers were first released and was very much drawn into its beauty and the mystery that was portrayed, thinking there will an unexpected twist or ending, but there wasn't, so I walked out of the theatre slightly dissatisfied and with a lot of questions.I knew I liked the movie because it's beautiful and I felt the chemistry between Edith and Thomas, I thought they both played their part brilliantly and their feelings were very believable, I also enjoyed watching Lucille. But I was undecided yet whether I should have loved it because something didn't make sense yet. I was equally dissatisfied that I had to believe Del Toro really just spend all his energy building this beautiful set, the costumes and completely disregarded the plot? All the reviews I later read were also split between dissatisfied viewer's criticism on the plot with the appearance of the ghosts for what? and fans with repetitive praise over the visual effects. later when I thought through the movie scene by scene, it all became clear to me, and it was apparent I had my energy and focus on the wrong expectation and missed the point of the movie. I would like to blame the trailers... "This is not a ghost story, it is a love story with ghosts in it..." Edith tells this to Thomas in one of their exchangesWe have to really realise that Crimson Peak is not a narrated by anyone else but Edith herself, no one else is telling us this story but Edith. And in fact it is the very story Edith had been writing throughout the movie, that love story with ghosts in it.."The ghosts are merely metaphors of the past..."Someone in a review asked why Edith's mother's ghost came to warn her about Crimson Peak but her dad's ghost never came to warn her? The ghosts are not real, they were merely metaphors, The Sharpes targeted widows and their lone daughters and it is the time when Edith's mother died that Edith became a destined victim, the ghost that came to warn her is a metaphor of this destiny. Do you remember the encounter at the publishing house? Edith runs into the mother of Sharpe's original chosen victim, in response to her attacking Edith:"you will die a spinster" Edith rebels to her saying:"I would rather be Mary Shelley and die a widow (referring to back to her)" is a subtle confirmation of the criteria the Sharpes used to choose their victims.The other ghosts were also woven into the story by no other than Edith herself as she recollects her time at the Aderllel Hall, from the first time she enters, the eerie feelings it may have given her and all the supposed secrets it was hiding. Many in their reviews asked why is it that the Sharpes can not see them? they are not hallucinations and they are not ghosts she actually saw but metaphors of what was hidden, the secrets.Many other 'plot holes' also start to make sense once you realise the story is told by Edith. I initially spent some time contemplating the time when Thomas showed up wet at Edith's house after being in the rain for a long time, it was never explained later what caused him to do so, had he fallen in love with Edith at first sight at her father's office? Did he think she had more money that the other chosen victim? Perhaps he thought she was an easier target to sign her fortune away. It was never explained, and rightly so, because whatever the truth is, Edith or anyone for that fact would never know, and will never know...But this is Edith's love story, it's about her love, her doubts and her pain. Every scene is actually a recollection from her point view, a young girl falling in love for the first time and experiencing through an horrific discovery of secrets hidden from her. Every scene is in the perspective of Edith and no one else, the observations were Edith's observation, it was entirely her world. Once the point of view becomes clear you will find how impeccable everything is about this movie, it's casting, set and even the language.I do think though that the build up to the movie had mislead many looking for a horror story or ghost story, but I also enjoyed the discovery process. Realising this now I can't wait to watch the movie again. A Gothic romance in very fine form.

Review title: The Worst Movie I've Ever Seen
Review_body: This movie was so awful I could hardly believe my eyes. I've never written a review before, but I strongly believe that I have a responsibility toward the human kind to warn you. DON'T WASTE 2 hours of your beautiful life watching this... thing. My friend George says that this movie could be a good cult movie. Kate was apologizing all night for making us see it.
