Review title: Beautiful and dark Gothic horror movie.
Review_body: Movie reviewsI was very excited to watch Crimson Peak. I was expecting a dark story and rather gruesome supernatural characters, judging from Guillermo del Toro's previous work (still have nightmares about that creature with eyes in its palms in Pan's Labyrinth). The supernatural elements are few and very delicately positioned. There aren't a lot of horror elements just for the sake of horror. They are all part of the story. The ghost figures are shown as these dark mangled skeleton figures, covered in black or blood red clay. The their eyes looks chillingly human and tortured. Although they look scary and upsetting, they do not pose a threat to the living. The real threat is very much alive. Furthermore, Edith is the only one who seems to see the ghosts and even though they scare her, they do not wish to harm her, but rather try to help her. Crimson Peak (Allerdale Hall) is magnificent from the inside as well as outside. The huge mansion stands alone on a bare heath. The long driveway is covered in red clay. When Edith first enters the house the leaves are falling through the roof into the middle of the foyer. There is a huge gaping whole in the middle of the house where the roof collapsed, leaving the foyer open to the elements. The foyer is surrounded with massive staircase leading to different parts of the house. There is also and old metal elevator running through the house and into the bowels of the clay mine which is situated right underneath the house. The red glow of the clay makes it look like the way to hell itself. The basement, where the clay is stored, is an interesting space with dome like ceiling where the light and snow falls into the room. During the winter months the whole estate is covered in snow. The grounds around the house however turn red, when the snow falls on the red clay. It looks like the house is bleeding and the blood is seeping out of its deep wounds. The house is full of wonderful rooms, exquisitely furnished and now sinking into decay, the same as their owners. The house and their inhabitants seem equally damaged and full of ghosts of the past. If there was ever a perfect Haunted Mansion this is it! Costumes are another thing that makes this movie worth watching. I love the beautiful fusion of different styles. Edith's old high-necked evening coat as well as her puffed up sleeves on her morning dress. The colors the characters tend to wear are also a reflection of their character and true nature. Edith wears lots of yellow dresses. She is like one of those butterflies we see at the beginning of the movie. Thomas and his sister Lucille with their dark color wardrobes resemble moths, which as Lucille says "eat butterflies". More than just a ghost story it is a story of love. It shows how love or the lack of it can damage, destroy, heal and bring back ghosts. The main love story between Edith and Thomas is short lived and tragic. Even though we find out that their marriage was based on a lie, Thomas's love for Edith was real. She is the first person he truly loves and I think his love for her sets him free at the end. The love between Thomas and his sister was born from the lack of love from their parents. They only had each other for a long time and with time their love grew into a deadly poison which was destroying them and everyone who came near them. Edith arrives and brings hope to Thomas of another, better and brighter life. His sister cannot find peace even in death. Her ghost remains in the house, playing the piano, clinging onto her strong emotions of love and hate. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. Its story and its characters are well layered and full of little metaphors. And above all the house is truly a masterpiece.

If you are fan of deltoro i beg you dont watch this movie. The screenplay is like joking i was shocked every minute and i don't why they made such a disaster just enjoy with cinematography and music a little bit.

I was excited to see this movie and couldn't wait. That ended not long after the movie started. It was super slow and really drug out and I actually saw people fall asleep in the theater. I was really hoping once they got through the initial plot set up it would get better, but nope. Then there were the graphics which really surprised me at the lack thereof. It was stuff you see school projects. Very clay-mation or something like that. Anyway, the plot left holes, which I don't mind for #2 but there should never be a number 2 on this movie. I did have on jump but there were several times that if you have EVER watched any scary movie you could say, here it comes and sure enough there it was so there was NO jump or scare just, yep saw that coming 2 minutes ago. Not surprising how fast it was gone from theaters. I expected more from Del Toro.

Awful with a capital A. Not even a true horror flick. Chastain was great but that's about all the good I can say about this film. Hiddleston should stick to Shakespeare or Thor. I am a fan of Hiddleston but this is not a good vehicle for him. Del Toro has done much better work in the past. Hopefully, he'll come back much stronger with his next film. The suspense was predictable and boring. The cinematography was good. The sets and costuming were okay but nothing to write home about. Best spend your money elsewhere. There are lots of good movies coming. In closing take a pass on this one. Might be okay to watch on TV when it gets there but save your money for now.

A story everybody has seen a thousand times. There is nothing original in it. I knew what would happen in the first 20 minutes. It tries to be artistic and has nice colours but still falls flat. The supernatural elements add nothing substantial to the story. Definitely a wasted potential.
Felt I was watching something Edgar Allan Poe or Mary Shelly would've imagined, told or narrated and I loved that.
Tradition in the Gothic sense of literature. Macabre and taboo in the modern senses. And classic film tropes of suspense films from the visual artist himself, Guillermo del Toro.

Review title: How can people not like this movie
Review_body: Im shocked that some people don't enjoy this movie. So shocked that I had to leave a review and I never do that so...if you're thinking about watching this movie please do it's creepy, and very beautiful.

This movie is terrible. It seems like it was made for the sole purpose of being as weird and as twisted as possible. "You know what's dark? A guy who marries women and kills them for their money." "You know what's even darker? A guy who does all that because he's in an incestuous relationship with his older sister." You get the feeling early on that there's something strange between the brother and sister, and in the back of your mind, you're thinking, "I really hope this doesn't end up being one of those weird brother-sister things." And then it does. The most original twist in the movie is that you're supposed to believe that the sister has killed not only three of the brother's wives, but also one wife's child--it turns out that the child is actually the sister's and died from being malformed and sick.Regarding the horror, this movie is not remotely scary. The visuals of the ghosts cease to be scary when the first one appears. There is so much CGI put into them that it looks overdone and super fake. Ghosts need to be done with a light touch because familiarity with monsters takes away their scariness.As for the acting, it wasn't bad but the only one worth mentioning is Jessica Chastain, who plays Lucille Sharpe. She's really good as the creepy, twisted, and perverted older sister.And as for the writing, I never believed that the characters Edith and Thomas were in love because the courtship part of the story seemed rushed. And the awkward and dry sex scene did nothing to convince me.Oh, and normal people can't bleed as much as these characters did without dying. So, is there anything good about the movie? There a few small things:1. Wardrobe: The filmmakers wanted Edith to stand out, not only from the villains, but also from the side characters. Edith was usually seen in bright colors and has blond hair; everyone else was in dark colors and black. 2. Literary References: During the film, there are three references made to some of the best novelists of the 19th century: Jane Austin, Mary Shelley, and Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. Which is strange, because writing seems to take center stage early on, and is then swept aside completely in the second act. 3. Paranormal Theory: Early in the film, the character Dr. Alan McMichael (Charlie Hunnam) discusses how he believes that ghosts are tied to certain places because of stone or mineral deposits in the earth. This is an actual theory in the modern ghost hunting community, but I'm not sure if they were aware of this fact in the Victorian period.In conclusion, I cannot recommend this film to anyone. It is daytime TV tripe. Don't go see it.

Where to begin? The music was solid as well as the acting. The set pieces, especially the house were beautiful. The costumes and general feel were authentic. The story however, was predictable and boring. After 40 minutes I was still waiting for the story to kick in only to realize that it already unfolded.The ghosts play a very small part in the story and the jump scares were cheap. The CGI however was not half bad. The twist was predictable and I did not care about the characters or what could happen to them. All in all, very disappointing. People who rate this more than 7 have probably seen too few good movies. PS: The movie's plot is actually 4 to 5 plots from other classic movies mashed in one.

Underrated movie, great special effects, it has everything, love, hate, sex, deceit, ghosts, thrill, the pretty and ugly places. Love the imagery, great cast. Great film. Guillermo del Toro's best work in my opinion.

Review title: Skip seeing the movie and go straight to stabbing yourself in the eye with a fork
Review_body: Imagine a completely humourless instalment of A Series of Unfortunate Events in which a young Count Olaf seduces Violet's dim-witted older cousin and takes her to live in his haunted red paint factory. Throw in some incest and a lot of graphic violence. Or skip seeing the movie and go straight to stabbing yourself in the eye with a fork.The plot is one long cliché - lonely young woman moons over handsome mysterious stranger, moves to isolated house where terrible secrets of the past emerge to the accompaniment of loud noises, scary music and special effects. Much blood is spilled before the heroine and her rescuer emerge slightly the worse for wear but still alive. The setting was depressing rather than eerily atmospheric. The acting was stilted and drab, the Edwardian era costuming shiningly synthetic. The special effects seemed designed primarily to showcase the amount of money and effort put into them.

Review title: Sir Thomas Sharpe woos young author Edith Cushing and brings her as his bride to his mansion. There, Edith meets ghosts and she discovers a dark secret. She must escape.
Review_body: I am not a horror film fan, however, I was extremely exited to see this film. I was very disappointed. My friends (4ppl) and I saw it on Friday night and we all were disappointed.There were so many plot holes and the story was so contrived. The starts are for the cast, cinematography, costume, and production design. These made the film look so beautiful.As I've stated above, I am not a horror film fan. Due to sensitive dreams, I stay away from horror films or anything that is gory. However, this film was not scary. I was able to sleep with the lights off when I go home. All the scenes that could have been scary were shown in the trailer. I would not recommend this film to see in theater. This is a stay home and watch movie.

Let me begin this review by putting everything into perspective for you: Hey, it was free! And those words pretty much summarize my feelings regarding Crimson Peak. I saw the trailer a few weeks ago and was intrigued by it. A historical ghost story is a pretty enthralling category to start. I wouldn't say I had high hopes for this movie, necessarily, but with Jessica Chastain and Tom Hiddleston to its name, I thought it would at least have a bit more credibility. We begin the movie with our main character, Edith, trying to shop out her manuscript. Shortly thereafter, she first runs into Thomas Sharpe. He is alluring, but ultimately Edith decides to keep her distance. Later, you have the standard 1800s-era waltz scene, where Thomas demands Edith as his partner and all the women oogle at the pairing. Her father, at odds with Thomas, takes matters into his own hands as their nonexistent, chemistry-less romance flourishes (flounders would be a more accurate word, because apparently Edith falls in love after one dance, which...um, okay). He uncovers something about Thomas and his sister, Lucille, and warns him that he better leave. He even pays him off to do so. This brings the first of my gripes. There was never any real suspense set up, because there were scenes between Thomas and Lucille to show that they're not "good"; we knew they had malicious intentions. I think it would have been more effective to confuse the audience, to let us piece it together along with Edith. Instead, we were handed all the plot foreshadowings on a platter and had each one pointed out to us, labeled, and described. Not the most effective tactics, mind you. My second complaint is directed to whomever did the transitions between scenes. I know the tunnel-out was purposeful, an artistic choice or whatever, but every time the circle paused on the main focal point of the scene and it faded to black I was jerked out of the story. It was extremely campy and it pretty much stole all remaining credibility from the movie, at least in my opinion. That's pretty much all the strength I have for summarizing left in me, so let me touch upon some of the most unbelievable things (and not in the dictionary-definition "so good it's unreal" way--I'm talking about the "honey, it's absolutely unbelievable that you gambled away all our money last night" way). 1) Mia Wasikowska's acting: I really liked her in "Jane Eyre", so believe me, I'm not saying she's a bad actress or anything. I just didn't love her acting in this. My mom's friend, who saw the movie with us, first pointed it out. I had thought something was maybe off about her scenes, but that cemented it for me. Her acting was just not very good. Any and all emotional reaction from her seemed extremely fake and forced, and her voice veered into wooden territory many a time. I just don't think this was the role for her. 2) The violence: I had no idea this movie would be so violent. It was more violence than it was horror, really--especially near the end. Something does happen in the beginning, though, that's pretty graphic, and arguably maybe the most graphic happening. The violence was all pretty visual and the shock-factor was there, but it went so over-the-top at the end of the movie that--wait for it--we started laughing. In the theater. The most unbelievable thing happens when (MAJOR SPOILER) Lucille stabs Thomas. Okay, we get that. She's knife-happy. But then she stabs him again, and then she just kind of--well--she pretty much jams the knife into his cheek. Yeah. It wasn't beautiful. The horrible thing is, I had to stifle a giggle. I think I was grinning in disbelief. And later, after we were out of the theater, I laughed aloud thinking back to that scene. It was so over-the-top that it, again, completely jarred me out of the movie and so blunt and so ridiculous that I just had to laugh. Hence the title "Crimson Comedy". Later, my Mom actually did laugh, when amidst silence and tension Edith hits Lucille over the head with a shovel and it produces this ringing, cartoon-esque booooing. She had to cover her mouth in the theater to stop herself, and then I started laughing, because it really was ridiculous. So, yeah: if you want a couple of incredulous laughs, this movie's for you! The good, redeeming things about this movie are that first, it was watchable. It might have been terrible, but it was a watchable terrible. Second, it did have some good moments. Jessica Chastain is the best, and I've thought that since seeing her in "The Help". Its amazing to me that she can go from a character like Miss Celia to Lucille with so effortlessly, and made even more so by the fact that, even with Miss Celia's "This. Is. So. Fun!" ringing in my ears, I still believed her as Lucille. I would argue that the most poignant part of this movie is when Lucille whips around with the pan in her hand and almost hurtles it toward Edith. First, because it gave us a clean-cut, uncontrolled view into her crazy mind. It was unsettling because you could see the insanity in her eyes, because it was such a close call, and because she was just barely coherent enough not to do it. That was a scene that wasn't handed to us. They didn't point to Lucille's insanity with words but rather let her actions speak for themselves, as they should have done the entire movie.Overall,this was kind of terrible, and I wouldn't watch it again. 2/10, don't recommend, unless you want it to prompt some inappropriately-timed laughter on your part.

So without spoiling this movie, it doesn't make any sense. Sure it's beautiful to look at it, in a music video kind of way. (Although the ghosts are way too polished to be scary.) The problem with this movie is that the setup, the trailers, etc, don't do as advertised. I wanted to like this movie, i like Charlie, Mia, Tom, etc but they are working with such a hokey/super campy script that it pulls you straight out of the narrative. i wanted so much more! Also as bad as the opening the act is, it's actually way better than the third act. (middle act is so-so) So with that said, wait for hbo/redbox, it's something you'll be annoyed you spent 12 bucks for. on a side note Tom Hiddleston did prove to be decent actor outside of Loki. I'd love to see him in a well written movie

This movie offers nothing but the looks which is quite nice... other than that... hilariously bad. No story whatsoever, most useless ghosts I've ever seen, too much of the color crimson and not scary at all (unless you count the jump scares every other second which is just annoying). The characters seem to not even feel their mayor injuries (e.g. when Edith falls from the stairs and breaks her back... some minutes later she runs and fights... yeah sure, how convincing). The others also manage to stay alive after fatal injuries. WTF. There are huge gaps in the "story" if you can call it that at all. Sometimes I had to laugh at the so called "scary" parts. Sometimes I just didn't get what the F* this film was about. So well done! Pointlessly wasted 2 hours of my life.

Review title: A list actors churching up a bad plot
Review_body: I went to see this 10/15/15 with a friend. He bought the tickets, so I'm not too upset at having seen the movie. The actors in the movie are all great. I believe they did the best they could with the script. The plot, however, was terrible. Thirty minutes into the movie and I wasn't sure if I was watching a horror movie or a old time love story. Without giving away spoilers, progression was slow. The end was very anticlimactic. You pretty much knew what was going on the entire time. It also leaves a ton of unanswered questions that probably would have been pretty cool plot points. 4/10. Don't waste your money in theaters. Wait for Redbox and the $1 rental.

A great fantasy/mystery thriller! The kind that made me feel bitter sweet as watching thinking after this i'll probably have to wait another decade to maybe yet again enjoy such film. I don't quite understand the negative reviews and it seams almost unfair that this movie did not hit above 7 (considering other fantasy movies that did yet turned out to be mare 90210 syrups). The cast is great, acting rocks, visuals are stunning and the atmosphere carefully produced. Yes there might be historical inaccuracies and all i have to say about that is: it's a fantasy movie, man, don't look for it in history books. As for horror- wise it might not be the most creatury feature out there yet it possesses one of the most beautifully balanced real/fantasy horror notes. There is supernatural yet the supernatural is but emphasis to the real evil, the one that is incarnate here, flesh and blood. Definitely worth a watch when one needs a bit of that escape reality feels. I rarely feel i could watch a movie of the genre over again particularly not after just having seen it and with this one, i just might!

Review_body: After reading some of these in depth reviews there's no way I could ever miss this.

Review title: What Del Toro lacks in foreplay, he makes up for in fireworks. And although not his best display, it's hard not to gaze up at in the October darkness and get lost in.
Review_body: As is always the case with Guillermo Del Toro and his dark fairy tales, the art direction and cinematography in Crimson Peak is stunning. Step for step with the anthropomorphic architecture is Kate Hawley's costume design, a showcase of ruffled and laced Victorian gowns drenched in deep blues and crimsons for the ominous, and veiled coppers and beiges for the less assuming. Aesthetically, it demands to be seen.A self-proclaimed Gothic romance, Peak follows Mia Wasikowska's Buffalo, New York Industrial Era ingénue, Edith Cushing, and her dreams of turning a haunted reality into print fiction. Before her pen turns to type, enterprising outsider Thomas Sharpe(Tom Hiddleston)and his eerie, yet elegant sister Lucille(Jessica Chastain) supplant her notions of normalcy and her sunny, Western New York sky turns endlessly obsidian. Although creepy throughout and quite literally set in a house of Technicolor horrors, Peak is far from a horror movie, which the film's marketing department did a pretty bad job of...marketing. The weakness in the film is in its screenplay, which doesn't do a great job of burying the twist or fleshing out most of the leads (specifically Wasikowska and Charlie Hunnam's characters). Even without a wealth of meat to work with, Tom Hiddleston is indefensibly charming as he wades through his murky inventions and intentions and Jessica Chastain is all-in, stealing the show with a devilishly unhinged performance of a woman fraying at the seams of her questionable intent. What Del Toro lacks in foreplay, he more than makes up for in fireworks. And although not his best display, it's hard not to gaze up at in the October darkness and get lost in.

Review title: Definitely not a blockbuster horror movie so if you're into that don't watch
Review_body: The story is slow and easy to guess and the plot twists are quite dull. There aren't many horror factors since it is more about the love stories. The visuals and the acting, however, is brilliant. The house that "breathes, bleeds and remembers" definitely adds up a creepy feeling to the movie. The ghosts in the house are beautifully made but aren't even scary, their jobs is to make people feel sympathetic. The protagonists Lady Lucille and Sir Thomas are perfectly portrayed but i'm not sure about Edith. You can feel how evil but also heart-broken Lucille is when she angrily stabs Thomas , you can see the overwhelming sorrow in Thomas's eyes when he looks at Edith and Lucille... Oh how I love the acting. "Crimson Peak" overall is a good movie if you are into dark, twisted love stories with a tiny dash of horror.

Review title: Overstated metaphor meets period drama with an Edge
Review_body: I went into this movie without reading any criticism as I am a huge fan of Del Toro's and I get shivers every time I see Del Toro with a writing and/or directing credit. If you're expecting Pan's Labyrinth level of originality, look elsewhere. If you are expecting a ghost story with thrills and jumps, although there may be a few, look elsewhere. If you are expecting a sit-on-the-edge-of-your-seat suspense -horror, look elsewhere.If you're looking for a romance film that is beautifully shot and acted, and that plays out as the story goes with a certain level of prediction, you've arrived at the right film (granted with quite a bit more "crimson" than any other romance I've seen). Del Toro takes a tired genre (how many Jane Austin films are there now?) and adds a twist to the genre. A gory genre twist. To put this film in the "Horror" category doesn't seem correct to me and honestly is somewhat misleading. It is more like "Hor-Drama". I have to admit the film was predictable, but I believe it was intended to be so. I don't necessarily think this film was intended to be super deep, or super secretive in its plot layout, much like the romance films in this period. Just like some similar period films, the facts of the story are presented from all angles, making the plot obvious to the viewer, but not the characters in the film, making the viewer attach to the characters that much more.Two downfalls I saw during this film. A lot of the character development happens within the last twenty minutes that the audience would already have known if they paid an ounce of attention throughout the beginning of the film. I felt myself identifying that I already knew these things about the characters, and frankly what could have been a climatic moment, was reduced to a moment of dull satisfaction. The metaphor of crimson peak is drilled into our brains over and over and over again throughout the film. This is potentially the one thing that could have been saved for the last possible moment in a great crescendo yet was given out too early in the film.Two greatness's I saw during this film.The direction is beautiful, as almost every scene could be a painting in and of itself. The characters are dressed and acted in exactly how they are meant to be portrayed. The acting (except for Charlie, not a huge fan) is spot on. Each character plays their role to a "T", nailing both the fragile innocence, and the dark hatred.6 out of 10 for this one.

My first opinion about this film was good. But after some thoughts I was disappointed. I want to see more fantasy in this film. It is just a thriller with great actors, great picture, deep atmosphere. Mia Vasikowska is beautiful. if you Like Del Toro's films you must see this film. there are many scary moments in that cinema. Also good visual effects and characters. I think that director try to discover for us some deep parts of characters souls. Atmosphere in film is Gothic and fascinating. Music is very beautiful and also scary in some moments of film. Guillermo del Toro is master of visual picture and atmosphere, but screenplay may be better

I expected a Gothic romance and got one. The horror is minimal and consists of mostly occasional gory images to shock. The scenery and the house that the story is set in were amazing and gorgeous. Loved the moths everywhere! But the actual story, to me, was tired and overdone. The moment he mentions the attic to Edith I thought "Oh, please don't go all Flowers In The Attic." And yet, it did. Bummer. Could have been a fabulous movie but I wasn't surprised at all after guessing that tired old plot trope. Chastain was awesome. I imagine the actors had a time dealing with all that vivid red clay, as well. Overall, not as ground-breaking or original as Pan's Labyrinth

Review title: What a boring film, full of plot holes
Review_body: I first realized this film was bad when they changed scenes with what looked like a crossover effect from a cheap movie maker. Whoever OK'd that should have been fired on the spot, but on top of that the film was boring. The only entertaining part of the movie was when Charlie hunnam was trying to solve mystery's. It was entertaining but the truth is that any 5th grader could have solved that crime. I still don't understand how the police didn't solve the mystery. The twist was predictable, and not shocking at all. The first half hour was mildly entertaining but just went downhill from there. Don't waste your time with this one.

Crimson Peak was a good film as a whole, but unfortunately the horror aspect was lacking. It is a gorgeous film, the way the shots are shown, lighting, costumes and setting, special effects, its a very visually impressive film. There is a scene towards the end involving a confrontation between Hunnam and Hiddleston and the shot of them standing in the door at the end of the fight with the winter storm in the background is my favorite in the whole film. It's not an original story and it is predictable, but its executed excellently by its main cast, especially by Hiddleston and Chastain playing the Sharpe siblings. Tom Hiddleston's performance was entertaining as always. He carries a special suave and charisma with his acting and it shows in his character. You know that there is something mischievous about him. His eyes are the most expressive feature of his person. Jessica Chastain's character was probably my favorite to be honest. I love Hiddleston, but Chastain's Lucille Sharpe character has just the right balance of insanity and caring sincerity when it comes to protecting everything that her brother and her achieved. This is a character that is up there with Essie Davis's Amelia (Babadook) and Julie Harris's Eleanor Lance (The Haunting). The rest of the cast did a good job. While I'm not a fan of Wasikowska's past characters like Alice from Tim Burton's Alice in Wonderland, she was fine as the main heroine of the movie. Charlie Hunnam is another actor that I enjoy watching when the role is right. I hated Pacific Rim and his role in Crimson Peak is a good one, but you could've gotten almost any other A- list actor and he probably would have had the same impact as Hunnam had on me. Again, its not a scary movie, atmospheric sure, and if you watch it in a theater the loud stingers might make you jump, but Del Toro himself said its not supposed to be a horror movie but a Gothic romance, which I completely agree. Sure the visuals of the ghosts are disturbing but its not nearly as jumpscare heavy as recent horror movies have been. The Gift is not even a horror movie but it still scared me more than this because of how realistic it is. My heart was pounding more watching The Gift then some of the jumps during this movie. I was more smiling and somewhat laughing listening to the audiences reactions then being scared myself. Final thoughts, a fantastic, visually outstanding film that is led by a great cast but unfortunately falls short on the horror side of it.

Review title: Tale of Horror + Detective + Love = Awesome movie!
Review_body: Excellent movie! Fantastic greasepaint and actor casting. Decoration and shooting. Great music and design of world. I excepted middle quality movie but I forget that producer of this is Guillermo del Toro Gómez! He create such film like "El labyrinth del Faun" and "El Orfanato". He can make any film better, especially if movie contain monsters. Love story in movie pretty boring but it not make you sad. Detective is predictable but some angle is not expected. Film contain several kills and they shoot perfect! If you love blood - you'll be happy. If you want film that you can watch with your girlfriend - It is excellent choose.If you don't have girlfriend then you can watch on your own, it's still be good movie for evening.

Review title: The Movie is good, beautiful, and amazing. But bit too predictable and bit too rush/
Review_body: First of all, I want to say sorry for my bad English, and grammar.I will give the score 7,5 out of 10. The movie is good, beautiful and amazing and I like the setting of story. But the movie is bit too predictable and bit too rush. But overall the story is good. And don't ask why, but I got bit turn on when I watched this movie.And, *Spoiler Warning!* I smiled and almost laughed when I saw the moment when the ghosts showed up and Thomas pulled out the knife from his face after got stabbed by his sister because of her jealousy. And I enjoyed the fighting scene between Edith and Lucile. It really made me excited when I watched it.And it's really sweet when I watched the relationship between Thomas and Edith, and Thomas fell in love with her because she is different (in my opinion different than his other wives(maybe) and women, because of her interest of ghosts and some of his work. Because in my opinion not many women in Victorian era interested with a men work especially the nobles).The movies is bit too predictable, especially the sharpe siblings relationship. I can predicted it when I watched the trailer few times, and bit too rush in love relationship between Edith and Thomas (which is still okay for me).But Overall, the movie is good and amazing. I will wait for another Guilermo's movie, and I will have a good dream tonight after I watched this movie.

Review title: not one of Guillermo del Toro's better works
Review_body: Completely predictable plot, overripe visually, excessively bloody, and a waste of some good actors and a director who is capable of much more (Pan's Labyrinth, for example)

thought i was sitting down watching one of this years best horror movies. well, i was not. on the other side i witnessed a bad story told by actors doing a mediocre performance. the overall look was good, and the production was proper made, however, I'm left with a feeling that i wasted 119 minutes of my life. the trailer is much much better than the final cut. i would not advice anyone to watch this. although the final message that it can be romantic to have a ghost in you house was not convincing enough. also explained badly. the excitement was non existing and it did not cost me to much to pick up my phone and play a board or two of Pet rescue.

Review title: I am not afraid of these ghosts. Where is the Horror?
Review_body: While the plot of this movie seemed very interesting, with a superb pallet of color, and Gothic theme, as well as a familiar face Tom, it just falls short of something really worth watching.I knew what was going to happen for the most part within the first 20 min of this movie. Only you will be waiting for something interesting to finally happen, and when it does, you just feel nothing(aside from a few gruesome scenes). This movie was just boring exposition, complete filler, and dare I say horrible acting from the main protagonist.It was like Misery, only it wasn't like Misery. It just sucked. Keeping someone captive to get something for yourself. Without the whole crazy about a book series, but about money."Look out behind you." at the end. Expecting to see the man who was stabbed only to see Thomas in his ghost form do nothing but stand there.Thinking back on this movie just gives me a brain aneurysm.The scary/horrific scenes were pretty gruesome (well a few were), but I just couldn't feel for the characters. The Gothic theme just wasn't enough to hold my interest in a movie filled with drab conversations and boring exposition.The entire Key missing scene was just horrible. Obviously the protagonist took it, who the hell else was going to take it, by that time you know the jig is up. Get the dumb woman to sign the paper and kill her. Why drag it out and have the doctor stabbed by Thomas only to be forgotten at the pivotal moment when he could have been the one to save her. He obviously showed interest in her from the beginning and throughout the movie.Why not go check the suitcase? Why tell her to stay out of the lower levels then not ever go down there until the end of the movie for a slasher flick session.Screw this movie for getting me interested in a ghost story only to be let down by a horrible execution.YOU WANT SOME TEA? ILL GET YOU SOME MORE TEA....

Just for the record, i'm not a fan of horror movies. The only reason i watched Crimson Peak was the director: Guillermo Del Toro. His previous movies showed that he is a genius whose mind is filled with creativity, moreover he is able to turn his visions into reality. He has a great sense to create unique worlds and his ability to balance CGI and practical effects makes these worlds more existing.I was terrified and amazed at the same time. Visually this movie is unexceptional, i wanted to carefully examine every piece of it, but the scary theme didn't "allow" me to immerse deep in this visual beauty for too long. The tension was built up well and constant fear of the unknown was in the air all the time. Music was a very good "wingman" of the thrill and well-timed sound effects added even more to the overall experience.Many famous trademarks of Del Toro were smuggled into the events successfully. The sets, make ups, costumes looked amazing, but (for me) the most impressing was the creative use of colours. The external and internal design of the house ensured a perfect environment for the creepy atmosphere. This atmosphere was the major element that captivated me from the beginning till the end. That thrill that carried me through the movie is hard to describe. I was under the influence of fear and anxiety, so all elements were in the right place to make your heart beat faster.Tom Hiddleston and Mia Wasikowska were great, but Jessica Chastain was clearly the one who almost stole the whole show. Her character was cold, seductive, mysterious and scary at the same time. I couldn't even decide whether to love or hate her.All in all, Crimson Peak is another masterpiece of Del Toro. I recommend this movie even for those who don't like horror movies, because this is one of the few that offers much more than jump scares and unimaginative stories.

Review title: A dark love story with a splash of gore.
Review_body: Crimson is "of a rich deep red color inclining to purple". It's a color of passionate love, seduction, violence, danger, anger, and adventure - all of which are contained in Del Toro's latest film, Crimson Peak.Guillermo del Toro is no stranger to adding detailed elements in a film to add depth, subtle or not. In Crimson Peak, his use of color and setting accompany the characters in a dark Gothic tale of love and deceit, with a sprinkle of suspense and gore that take the viewer on an enchanting experience. Rich color tones stylize the film for a gritty and unique ambiance. Edith, the main heroine, lives in a world where everything is dull and dark. But her presence, however, is evident in subdued yellows, greens, and neutral colors as she stands out in the world she resides in. Her pale skin and light hair also attribute to the innocence that she attains.The story itself takes the viewer down a dark path, following the love between two people from two different worlds. Del Toro was smart with the balance of action and build up. For just a brief time did the story feel slow, but it later facets to the build up of later scenes. Although this film wasn't as thrilling as I tend to prefer, it did a beautiful job of telling a dark love story that held hints of violence, making it just as enjoyable. I couldn't help but feel that Del Toro paid homage to some of the classics, such as The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari, Nosferatu, and even his own Pans Labyrinth and Mama with his use of transitions, shadows, symbolism, and sound.If you're looking for a film that is romantic with a dredge of somber, makes you uncomfortable yet hopeful, leaves you heartbroken but still enamored - all while being visually breathtaking, then Crimson Peak should be at the top of your list.

Review title: Its a sumptuous feast for the eyes
Review_body: Guillermo del Toro really knows how to draw you into his world and the depth of this pretty world is astounding. I mean if this doesn't win Oscar's for Set Design and Costume i'd be shocked. I found it eerie but not necessarily scary, but maybe that's just me. All the acting and actors are stunning and the love story is believable. Jessica Chastain's performance stands out (you can see why she's such hot property right now) but Tom Hiddleston and Mia Wasikowska are also truly wonderful as the lovers. Although I do believe Tom could charm a nun he's that convincing and he devours the screen in every scene.I was blown away by the set, the house and all it contained it was just so rich and delightful you just want to live in that set minus the ghosts for a little while, it's that inviting. It's perhaps the story itself that lets it down a bit. Let's just say it's not exactly something you haven't seen before in films. Not that i'm saying don't go see this film because it still has plenty to entice you.

Review title: Crimson Peak Starts Wonderfully But Then Disappears
Review_body: Del Toro's movie was just like Edith's book in the film. It needed more real romance, not some weird contrived romance that never felt real at all in any facet...and just missing something despite a lot of potential. So much wasted potential.I am very disappointed by this film. I was looking forward to something with Del Toro (as well as Hiddleston) for some time. While I'm not generally a fan of much horror I do tend to like Gothic romance. I feel that this story started out delivering all of that.I love the cinematography, the staging, and the costumes. Everything was gloriously detailed and lovely. I really enjoyed the amount of effort that went into the pictures as they were made. Sadly, the plot starts wonderfully and is even a bit surprising but then it falls flat and doesn't get up again. I'm not sure if parts were just a result of poor editing, or if it was planned to become dull after the trio move to England.The opening was really inviting, there was a lot of promise in the plot. Some of the hints for the future were a little obvious in my opinion but others were less so. I feel like the director must have been trying to insult people that like romance because there was incredibly little. There were a few lines that didn't feel all that romantic and instead felt a little more like bad smut novel lines. Once you get to England and the haunted house things just get weird. Half the time no one is around as Edith wanders about discovering all the murders that the siblings were up to. Edith is almost always left to her own devices while Thomas works on his red clay machine and his sister...plays the piano and I dunno...sharpens her knives? I guess they must have been off practicing the 'incest is best' mentality almost all of the time - to include the middle of the night. Why does she never ask her husband why he is never actually in bed with her? Is this for the same reason none of his marriages have been consummated without any questions? A tradition followed by law to this day. She just assumes all husbands don't want their wives? What? This was the first of many glaring issues.Why is the heroine first depicted as incredibly clever, self-reliant, and capable in the first half of the film? (Before they arrive at the crumbling manor - I now take this to be a symbol for what is about to happen to the movie.) All of these aspects sort of fall apart when she ignores all manner of clues despite previously noticing small details. When she, even though she has the money, just goes along with living in the estate at all when all logic dictates to not...yeah, well there goes a reasonably intelligent main character. Damn, we had one for the first half.Then suddenly he does have sex with her the night they're in town? Why? It was just ill-timed, forced, and awkward, not romantic. I think Del Toro just figured he'd sell the movie more if he added a bizarre Hiddleston sex scene.From the first scene with both siblings I knew they were shagging. It's not like it's a new theme for Del Toro. He's done it before. (Hellboy 2) It was overtly predictable and boring. Which leads me to believe he must have had some pretty unhealthy thoughts about his own sister. Thomas as a character felt worthless. Never was I convinced he actually loved Edith, I think he just really wanted to love her and wanted her as an escape from his abusive sister. I didn't feel bad for anyone. Thomas was a coward, that was pretty obvious and clear from the get go. Edith would have been good if she hadn't suddenly turned into a retard instead of seeking real help.The ending bothered me the most. The order of it was just all over the place. Thomas was bumbling about like the imbecile he is. He doesn't come to really mean much of anything. Edith saves herself and he just wanders in to his sister's lair. He might as well have just stabbed himself in the face and saved everyone else the trouble of his existence. His presence might have meant something if he would have walked in to declare that this wasn't okay and that he was going to let Edith go or that they'd live together or something in his crazy head BEFORE Edith had already saved herself. But since Edith had already seemingly stabbed the bitch in the heart (a lot of that pen went pretty deep) it wasn't really meaningful. That plot arrangement was just as pointless as the character, Thomas.Then crazy sister goes on a merry chase when she's been stabbed heavily near her heart. Cause you know, she wouldn't be bleeding to death or anything...evil people don't bleed, just not totally horrible ones. Then finally Edith doesn't get any real help from Thomas' ghost other than to function as the oldest trick in the book: 'hey look over there!' before she smashes in evil sister's head. Wow really? Worst ending I've seen in a long time. If at least he would have intervened before Edith saved herself then it might have had an ounce of feeling, but this was just poorly put together. So incredibly hollow, I'm sad good acting was wasted on that.

My girlfriend insisted on this movie rather than the Tom Hardy action flick LEGEND.Crimson Peak had my attention with how it LOOKED for about 15 minutes. The setting was believably authentic, the actors and actresses beautiful in all their movie star glory, and the imagery vivid. However, the plot was filled with cliché elements. For example, the incest element has been played to death by the hit show Game of Thrones, beautiful brother and sister sex simply does not arouse WOOs and WOWs any more. There is no play on the moral ground here, the audience nowadays are too morally desensitised by something like this. The "marry a rich woman only for her money" gambit is no shocker either. Bring me some real action, if i want to question human morality i simply have to go on youtube and enter search terms related to the Middle East and all its hideous violence. Crimson Peak, you are bland. Unbearably bland.In terms of being a horror flick, the suspense created in Crimson Peak does not cut it. You never feel that the protagonist Edith is in any real danger. The ghosts are dull and tasteless. There is no spite, no hate, no aggressiveness that you would normally associate with ghosts that have the back stories like they do in Crimson Peak. Make the ghosts do things, instead of having them crawl around like mindless zombies.Overall, my girlfriend is very satisfied with the movie because all that she is after is ogling at "Loki" from Avengers and Thor. She may even became moist when "Loki" and Edith engaged in some R-rated action in the wood cabin.If you have a choice, go see LEGEND, instead of this garbage. If you don't, make sure you buy plenty of comfort food so you can nom your way through this yawn fest.

The plot telegraphed everything so you know what is going to happen way before it does happen. The character development seems interesting, for about twenty minutes... The supernatural parts are brief and rather pointless. The decor and costuming come off as of only mild interest and the house itself... more pathetic than anything else. The acting was stiff and rather lame. The villains come off as incompetent, not particularly menacing. There is a small element of steam punk to it that feels thrown in for no particular reason. The landscape around the house was not spooky at all, but rather dry and sterile. Del Toro seems to think throwing in a bunch of insects adds something. It does add something, which is to make you wish you were watching a Peter Greenaway movie for real, instead. A Stephen King TV mini series would beat this by a country mile. Save your money.

Review title: A film so good, you'll have to see it twice to realize it
Review_body: As a die-hard fan of del Toro (Pan's Labyrinth has been my favorite film for some time now), I went into Crimson Peak with high expectations. Upon my first viewing, my opinion rested at a solid 8/10; it had beautiful production design and great performances, but the narrative seemed too lopsided and muddled.Then I saw it again.Seeing Crimson Peak for the second time was an indescribable revelation. Suddenly, every nuance of the performances made perfect sense, and the Gothic feel of the film, which easily eluded me the first time through, swept me up and carried me away, because I finally understood how the film was meant to be watched. The end of Pan's Labyrinth informed the beginning, but Crimson Peak is meant to be folded over on itself; only then can the depth of the narrative be understood. By the movie's nature, we only really discover what the story is within the final act, but when you watch it again, you realize that these realizations undercut the entire rest of the movie. No longer are you sitting around waiting for it to happen; it grabs you by the throat and keeps you there, transfixed. Now that I had the narrative under control, I was also able to begin to appreciate the incredible depth of the production design at play here. Some of the details are mind-blowing. What really changed, I think, about the second viewing was that I was able to step back and realize the immense amount of layering that had been poured into every single frame of the film, working on both visual and emotional levels. The pacing suddenly worked perfectly now that I knew what was going on, and I came to the conclusion that del Toro is simply a step ahead of all of us. I'm gravely disappointed that the reviews, especially those of critics, have mirrored the ignorance attached to a single, non-invested viewing. Crimson Peak is such a masterpiece that it's impossible to even realize its genius without diving headfirst into its folds. I could write a dissertation on the implications of this essential second viewing, but I'll spare you the details and stress to see this twice, preferably in IMAX.

Review title: Flower's in The Attic Meets Psycho
Review_body: Yes it was Gothic and the costumes were very sumptuous, otherwise this was slow, even though the romance felt rushed... and it just felt gimmicky in my opinion. Never felt scared. Tom was great as usual but this film did not do his career justice. His talent is too big for this Disney Haunted Mansion style movie, he and Mia's Father out acted all of them. Mia was OK but felt the actors talents were not fully utilized. This was like Flower's in the Attic meets Psycho filmed by Disney.What was the fading circle about? It felt like a Warner brothers bugs bunny cartoon affect when the circle faded away on the character in the shot.Although there were other decent actors in this film, sadly most of the acting felt forced and hollow. Again, except for Tom's and the Dad's. It's like their ability was greater then the script and it showed. The girl fight scene was just silly by the way.Chastain is usually very good in dramas, but the last two horror movies she attempted did not show her talents at all. She just seemed bitchy. There was once scene she did well in to show emotion on her face but otherwise not really impressed.An example of a great ghost story was THE OTHERS with Nicole Kidman in my opinion. The child actor's were excellent. Though Nicole isn't my favorite actor, she was good in that one.

Review title: I love Del Toro, or at least I did before Crimson Peak
Review_body: First of all, I'd like to say I really enjoy Del Toro's movies and therefore I went to the cinema quite excited, despite how little interesting I found the trailer. From the very beginning, and I mean, the first 2 minutes, I had this horrible feeling that the movie was going to be as bad as the trailer. ***SPOILER ALERT*** The first mistake, and the one that made me want to leave the cinema right away (because Del Toro is no amateur, he should've noticed this huge mistake): there is no way Thomas could've known the script of Edith was "good" and "about ghosts" by looking at it for less than 10 seconds. Well, I was eating some popcorn so I decided to stay. As soon as Lucille entered the scene, I whispered to my boyfriend's ear "yeah, Thomas and the sister have some kind of creepy mansion they can't leave, take Edith with them to get her money or maybe sacrifice her... but in the end, Thomas will face his beloved sister in order to save Edith. They'll probably both die, but Edith will be saved". It's not that I'm such a smart girl, it's only such a bad and predictable script. I know it's a horror movie and in horror movies, characters do stupid things (walking alone at night, going to check what was that noise, not grabbing a knife when there's danger ahead, and that kind of stuff), but Edith just goes to a new level of idiocy. And such an idiotic performance makes the movie feel UNREAL. None of us would act the way she did, because it's even against nature. I can believe - well, I don't- there's a ghost, but I can't believe someone won't realize Lucille is creepy af and is up to no good. The visual effects are little to no scary, nothing seemed real (something Del Toro usually excels at). But what I want to point out about the ghosts in this movie is the following: If you're going to introduce to the audience a ghost (which should be a main character since... it's a ghost-based movie) make them believe it's evil and then explain to them the ghost is actually a soul in pain, please, make the ghost important again. As soon as Edith finds out the ghosts are Thomas' murdered wives and Enola points out where Thomas and Lucille are having sex, the ghosts disappear completely from the movie. If the ghosts could open and shut doors, they could as well have helped her fighting Lucille, or something. Instead, Edith bangs Lucille in the head with a shovel and says -Men in Black style- "I heard you the first time". I laughed. It was hilarious. I left the cinema feeling insulted. Del Toro can do much better than this. It's pretty sad such a good director makes such a poor, mediocre film. (Sorry if there're mistakes, English is not my mother tongue.)

As other people has already mentioned, this work has got SO many things we've seen at del Toro"s movies that nothing comes by surprise... I hate a movie when you can tell the plot in advance, and especially when it goes from just OK to ridiculous. The end is bad, seriously bad. One expects laughs at movies with Freddy Kruger or Jason Voorhees, but when you hear them at the end of a movie that pretends to be serious... that a complete fail, and that's what this movie is.There are too many things which are absolutely incoherent in this movie... from an architectonic point of view a house wouldn't have lasted centuries if built on such a clayey soil... or clay won't emerge from your ground floor when you have a basement underneath... or a mother's ghost warning her beloved daughter wouldn't be a dark scary one, but a pale figure full of sorrow and love. And then we've got those ghosts that stink of computer design... the most unconvincing ghosts I've ever seen on a movie, no matter how bad they might be.Certainly the last del Toro movie I'm watching until he stops producing absolute garbage.

Review title: So much potential, so many flaws
Review_body: Although aesthetically very pleasing, this del Toro venture unfortunately falls short in the story department.I really liked most of the director's previous films because they were in some way playful regarding the genre(s) they were associated with. Crimson Peak, however, is exactly how you would expect a Gothic Romance/Horror cross over to be - there is no twist or turn which isn't predictable a mile ahead. Different characters find out the same information, seemingly without much regard to whether what is being shown actually adds a new perspective for the viewer or not. I won't start listing plot holes here, but if it was possible to weave illogical character actions with stereotypical scenarios, this film would have made a sophisticated carpet. And if one was to argue that the story aligns itself with a traditional Gothic romance arc and, as such, celebrates the stereotypes attached to it, please someone explain why they felt the need to make the ghosts look like the dementors in Harry Potter. Visually, I suppose a style more in the fashion of the photographs shown very early in the film might have been more suitable if a celebration of nostalgia was the aim this otherwise inarguably beautiful film.It might have been easier to forgive the shortcomings in logic and character motivation if the film had been a bit more empathetic to its protagonists, but despite - in my eyes - marvellous performances by Chastain and Hiddleston, their characters weren't given enough scenes to make the viewer really care about their fate.Overall, I felt the film was a bit of a missed opportunity - the actors and production design were setting it up to be great, but it lacked the boldness and innovative bite to really use its potential of becoming a modern classic.

Review title: Pretty, Predictable Snore, Moments of Brutal Violence
Review_body: This movie is beautifully staged, costumed and shot but in desperate need of editing. The few horror elements are tacked on. My friend and I were both thankful we did not spend $18 bucks for IMAX. (For what, pray tell...floating blood drops and drifting snow?) I identified the killer and motive right away. A weak homage to classic Gothic horror movies. Certain moments took me right out of the film. (Why are they running around a freezing house dressed only in nightgowns? Bad beard!) This movie desperately needed a young Vincent Price and a less bland hero and heroine. Suggest you find a copy of House of Usher, The Pit and the Pendulum, or Masque of the Red Death instead.

Review title: Was this made as a Tax write off?
Review_body: There nothing wrong with the acting. There nothing wrong with the cinematography. There nothing wrong with the effects. There is everything wrong about the concept.Please don't tell me I do not understand del Toro. I understand good story telling and this is not good story telling. This could have made a good Hammer Horror revival if it didn't take itself so seriously. There is no tension and no surprises. The only horrific thing about this movie was that it got made, with a big budget behind it.! Its not the worst move I've seen but its in the top 5. I dread to think what might knock it out of the top 5! It deserves a 1 but I've given it a 2 because of a great line at the end. If it had more of those laughs it could muster being a cult movie , but quite frankly its not original enough. Crimson Peak should be renamed Crimson Weak.

Portrayed to be a horror film through the commercials; however, it is the exact opposite. Crimson Peak is not what it seemed to be, in fact it is more of a suspense: keep you wondering what was truly going on kind of movie. The movie starts at the funeral of Edith Cushing's mother (Mia Wasikowska). The night of the funeral the mother visited Edith in the form of the ghost; she told the young Edith to be wary of the Crimson Peak. Not until she meet Thomas Sharp did she understand the warning her mom gave her.I went into this movie expecting a horror film, but I was pleasantly surprised to find out that it was a thriller. I thought that this movie was genius, Guillermo Del Toro did it again with this film. The whole movie you are wondering whether or not you are able to trust Thomas Sharpe and his sister after Edith moves to Allerdale hall in Cumberland. The movie was brilliantly written as well as being visually stunning. From the decaying-state of Allerdale hall to the piercingly-vibrant colors throughout the movie.Some people are saying that this movie is similar to Pan's Labyrinth in the way that it is dark and dreary. To a certain extent I can agree with these people both movies are dark; and both lead female actors acquire help from strange creepy entities not of this world. Aside from these points the movie stands alone. I would give this movie a seven out of ten stars, "beware of the Crimson peak!"

OK, i just saw the movie on a 60 inch hdtv and i can say only what my title says.... When you see trailer you expect that will be a good horror-atmospheric movie with many horror feeling scenes that can trigger that emotion of ''fear'' you expect. I liked a lot the acting from all actually,,especially Jessica Chastein as the cold blood sister was awesome but this is so far my enjoy goes. Very good Gothic atmosphere but for some unexplained reason,it felt like everyone and everything was holding back from director's unreasonable way to keep that slow plot with no great horror scenes,that spoiled all the movie i expected to see so long time. Last years every horror movie i saw was at least bad with no plot at all and as for acting don't mention it at all... That's why i was very disappointed about that movie,,cause i had big expectations.It could be far better with some better scenes,,actors after all were great in bottom line but the plot it self it was so little for them that could be a great movie with a few changes in storyline. Ghosts you see in the trailer and you think the story will be actually more relative with them it comes secondary and most of the times you forget you see a ghost story like the trailer. Anyway.... i gave 5 only for acting and atmosphere,plot takes a big 0 as it was too bad for my tastes and expected something more relative to the unknown behind the vale of natural.

Crimson Peak - I can appreciate the detailed and intense work that went into this film but it failed on many levels. Just because something is "gothic" does not give license to offer a poorly-developed plot which even a bored child would effortlessly pick through and conclude it unconnected, inadequately explained and underdeveloped. Examples include the sudden deep "love"(?)felt between the major protagonists,(where did that one come from?), lots of fluttering butterflies inexplicably on their way to an inevitable death, laughable cardboard cut-outs of the shambolic ancestral home and its immediate environment that should have been condemned by anyone still sane. Sorry, I do like a good pot-boiler but this one lacked everything apart from its gorgeous costumes and interior decorations. Maybe start with a good, tight and solid tale next time because I was left completely deflated. This was more like a pastiche and a poor one at that. Try again.....

In general, the movie was very remarkable. I love Victorian themed props and decorations as much as I do Castles and Mansions. At first I thought this movie was tiresome but about halfway it started to really catch my consideration. I was not expecting the end at all but I didn't really know what the movie was about till I started watching it. I was expecting more of horror genre theme movie but this was more of a suspense/thriller in my opinion. Guillermo del Toro did not let me down with this just like he hasn't with any of his other movies I've seen. I can't even really say that there was a movie like this that I've seen to compare it with. Have to watch this.

Review title: If your time is worth nothing, this is the movie for you.
Review_body: Hackneyed. Every. Single. Part. Nothing new. Nothing interesting. If you offer up a guess as to what you think will happen at the beginning, chances are you're probably right. An all star cast, with nothing to show for it in the end. If it were another director/cast, I might have ventured a 3 or 4 simply because of the artistic nature, but when they set the bar high, expect a hard fall when expectations aren't met. And holy crap were expectations not met. So, in conclusion, if you're in for the night and your choices consist of an Andy Griffith Show marathon and watching Crimson Peak for the first time (who would watch it a second time; I'm slightly embarrassed I watched it a complete first), then either make do with the marathon, or punch yourself in the face with an iron. That is all. Wait. Really really bad. OK, that is all.

Not action horror.I'm not sure about other countries, but trailers here made this movie look like a slasher, fast, action horror when really it was closer to a Gothic romance one. I think the movie suffered from miss-marketing and people went in thinking this was something it's not.The sets, costumes and ghosts were all beautifully designed. I'd expect nothing less from Guillermo del Toro though.The characters were interesting and I want to especially emphasize how much I loved Jessica Chastain in this. She did so well in making her character as eerie to watch as possible, like you know there's more to her there.
She was legit scary at the start, without needing a hockey mask and a machete.The story was engaging, even if other's might think it would be too slow, I felt like I was on the edge of my seat, trying to piece together the puzzle on what's going on in that mansion.As someone who's tired of the jumpscare-riddled, overly gory and big chested, screaming "high schooler" horror movies out there, this one was a big win in my books and a breath of fresh air.
Gothic Horror style but very predictable plot. Everyone acted their part well with few surprises.

Excellent casting. Amazing,mysterious,dark atmosphere that will have you hooked in no time! A movie so dark and mysterious,with some "gothic"vibes that will appeal to anyone who loves mystery in a mix with dark romantic features and Victorian aesthetic.Plot twists that you can barely imagine, amazing actors and the scenery is terrific. A dark,romantic and rather sweet but also horrific story dealing with the feelings of love,hate,madness,paranoia,devotion,loneliness,abandonment..An absolutely worth-seeing movie! T*SPOILERS* The only thing that could be better is the ghosts. They are not scary enough,they are rather silly. Kids will surely find them terrifying,but the movie isn't for kids anyway..Ghosts were made like this in purpose,it is a new technique. Some might find them fine
Best scenery, best production, best actress, best music... Must watch this movie.. The best horror moviessssssssssssssss...
